revision.text:
{{one source|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox person |image = |image_size = |alt = |birth_name = Gennady |birth_date = {{Birth date|1948|12|15|df=y}} |birth_place = Sovkhoz 42, [[Omsk Oblast]], [[Soviet Union]] |nationality = {{USSR}} {{RUS}} |known_for = Prominent figure of civil society movement of the USSR;
Founding social innovation movement in the USSR;
Founding the [[Foundation for Social Inventions]] of the USSR;
Founding Europe-America 500 consortium. |education = |alma_mater = [[Novosibirsk State University]] |spouse = Irina Alferenko |children = Olesia |parents = |awards = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Gennady Alferenko''' (Russian: Генна́дий Петро́вич Алфере́нко; born December 15, 1948) is a Soviet and Russian social innovator; in 1970 he established ''Terpsichore'', the first local community organization registered as a [[legal personality|legal entity]] in the [[USSR]]; in 1985 he established the [[Foundation for Social Inventions]] of the USSR, and in 1987, the foundation for Social Innovations USA. Alferenko is an Honorary Citizen of [[New Orleans]], [[San Francisco]], [[San Diego]], [[Atlanta]], [[Juneau]], and [[Seattle]]. ==Education and career== Gennady Alferenko studied [[Geology]] and [[Geophysics]] at the [[Novosibirsk State University]] from 1966 through 1973. During this period, in 1970, Alferenko founded Terpsichore, a [[ballet]] club, which was the first local [[community organization]] registered as a [[legal personality|legal entity]] in the [[USSR]]. Terpsichore organized events with performances of Soviet and world culture stars, such as [[Galina Ulanova]], [[Maya Plisetskaya]], [[Ekaterina Maximova]], [[Alicia Alonso]], [[Vladimir Vasiliev (dancer)|Vladimir Vasiliev]], [[Maris Liepa]], and [[Mikhail Baryshnikov]]. Also, he established a network of 450 local foundations to provide financial, organizational, and legal support to youth initiatives across the Soviet Union. From 1973 through 1985 Gennady Alferenko headed the NSU's oil and gas deposits research team in [[Eastern Siberia]] and on [[Sakhalin]] island. In 1985, following Alferenko's publication on an idea of a national campaign to facilitate innovators and change-makers, [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] pledged his support and invited Gennady to Moscow to set up a national fund promoting social innovations. Alferenko established the [[Foundation for Social Inventions]] at the [[Komsomolskaya Pravda]] newspaper, as a readers' voluntary association, to implement initiatives facilitating creation and establishment of an open [[civil society]].{{cite book |last=White |first=Anne |date= 1999 |title=Democratization in Russia Under Gorbachev, 1985-91: The Birth of a Voluntary Sector |url= |location= |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] |pages=8, 99–101 |isbn= 0333747755}} The Foundation for Social Inventions established and provided organizational and financial support to over 300 non-governmental organizations using a unique mandate to launch new organizations under its auspices. Some of the initiatives that Gennady Alferenko launched with the FSI, were Siberia-Alaska in 1988, and [[Space Flight Europe-America 500]] in 1992. Siberia-Alaska was a project to establish a [[Visa (document)|visa]]-free travel regime for native families in order to reunite Soviet and American [[Yupik peoples|Yupik]] Eskimos in [[Chukotka Autonomous Okrug|Chukotka]], and open direct flights between Siberia, Russian Far East, Alaska and California. Before, those who wished to travel legally across the [[Bering Strait]] had to go round the world. [[Space Flight Europe-America 500|Europe-America 500]] was the first ever [[private spaceflight]] which was conceived with the aim to promote the use of technology once reserved for military forces. It was followed by a Russian-American [[entrepreneur]] exchange program promoting development of small and medium-sized businesses in Russia. During the course of the program, over 10.000 young unemployed people had been sent for 4-6-week internships in the United States for developing entrepreneurial skills and gaining experience. In 1987, Gennady Alferenko established the US Foundation for Social Innovations, which, jointly with the FSI of the USSR, launched the first student exchange programs between the USSR and the USA for 100.000 students, and organized a meeting of the [[Vietnam War]] US veterans and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]] Soviet veterans to develop mutual support programs and establish joint business ventures, such as manufacturing of [[prosthetics]] and [[wheelchair]]s. In 1989, Alferenko together with the Esalen Institute organized [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s first trip to the United States, arranging meetings for Yeltsin with President [[George H. W. Bush]], Vice President [[Dan Quayle]], National Security Advisor [[Brent Scowcroft]], former President [[Ronald Reagan]], and many other leaders in business and government. The trip covered eleven cities and fulfilled Yeltsin's dreams of seeing the [[Statue of Liberty]] and an example of a free enterprise economy. In mid-1990s, Alferenko had developed recommendations for Prime Minister [[Yevgeny Primakov]] to establish a state-owned company [[Rosneft]]. At the time, he had also been a founder and president of the club of friends of the [[Bolshoi Theatre]]. In 2000, Alferenko organized Ring-2000, a civic initiative to create a National idea bank for the new President of Russia, [[Vladimir Putin]]. The main events were held in Russia concert hall in Moscow linked with 33 Internet centers in universities across Russia, and were broadcast on national TV. Since 2000, Gennady Alferenko has been a member of board of directors of [[Standard Bank]], a board member of Valery Gergiev Charitable Foundation, and strategic advisor to national and international companies such as [[Gazprombank]], [[Ernst & Young]], [[DLA Piper]], and [[PwC]]. In 2016, he became a member of the board of directors at Hancock Jaffe Laboratories, a U.S. based company developing bioprosthetic medical devices providing treatments for cardiothoracic procedures.{{cite web |url=http://www.hancockjaffe.com/about/ |title=About Hancock Jaffe Laboratories}} ==References== Specific references: {{reflist}} General references: {{refbegin}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070707104647/http://www.biograph.ru/bank/alferenko_gp.htm Gennady Alferenko's biography] at the International biographical Center (Russian). *[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/25/world/us-style-philanthropy-gains-in-the-soviet-union.html?pagewanted=print&src=pm U.S.-Style Philanthropy Gains in the Soviet Union, New York Times] {{DEFAULTSORT:Alferenko, Gennady}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Soviet people]] [[Category:Soviet Union–United States relations]] [[Category:Russian activists]] [[Category:Novosibirsk State University alumni]] [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Gerald Ganglbauer | image = Gerald Ganglbauer 2015.png | alt = Photo of Gerald Ganglbauer | caption = Gerald Ganglbauer (2015) | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1958|02|24}} | birth_place = Graz, Austria | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Austrian and Australian | other_names = | known_for = Parkinson's ambassador | occupation = Writer and publisher }}
'''Gerald Ganglbauer''' (born 24 February 1958 in [[Graz]], [[Austria]]) is an Austrian–Australian writer and publisher diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] at the age of 48 years. Since then he has been an ambassador for Parkinson's support groups.
== Life == Born Horst Gerald Ganglbauer, he studied [[Communication studies|communication]] at [[University of Graz]] (1986), and more recently [[web development]] at the [[Sydney Institute of Technology|SIT]] (2006).<ref>[http://www.gangan.com/gg/en/about.shtml ''Gerald Ganglbauer'']. Website of Gerald Ganglbauer. Retrieved 11 January 2011.</ref> In 1984 he started the [[Small press|independent press]] ''Gangan'' with his then wife Petra Ganglbauer. After their divorce he lived for several years in [[Vienna]]. Since 1989 he has lived in Sydney and [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], Australia under [[dual citizenship]], and is listed as one of Styria's ''Top Expatriates''.<ref>[http://www.verwaltung.steiermark.at/cms/beitrag/10432592/10959229 ''Top Auslandssteirer Medien/Literatur'']. Website of the Styrian Government. Retrieved 27 January 2011.</ref>
1982/83 he was a founder and editor-in-chief of the magazine ''perspektive'',<ref>[http://www.onb.ac.at/oe-literaturzeitschriften/Perspektive/Perspektive.htm ''perspektive'']. In: Österreichische Literaturzeitschriften 1945–1990, ONB (Austrian National Library), Retrieved 21 January 2011.</ref> 1987/88 editor in chief of the literary journal ''gangan viertel, ZeitSCHRIFT über Literatur'',<ref>[http://www.onb.ac.at/oe-literaturzeitschriften/Ganganviertel/Ganganviertel.htm ''gangan viertel'']. In: Österreichische Literaturzeitschriften 1945–1990, ONB (Austrian National Library), Retrieved 21 January 2011.</ref> and in 1990/91 he launched [[Gangaroo]] in Sydney. In 1992 he co-edited with Andreas Puff-Trojan ''Textwechsel'',<ref>Andreas Puff-Trojan, Horst Gerald Ganglbauer: ''Textwechsel'', Sonderzahl, Vienna 1992, {{ISBN|3-85449-044-5}}.</ref> and in 1996 launched the international online magazine [[Gangway (magazine)|Gangway]]. In 2001 he introduced ''Gangart Awards'', an intercultural competition for the arts on the net, which were awarded till 2005 by an international jury, and only ended due to his illness.<ref>[http://www.gangart.com/awards/ Gangart Awards]. Site Redesign Competition, Retrieved 21 January 2011.</ref> ''Gangan'' published books in print for ten years, and then online.<ref>[http://www.gangan.com/books/ ''Gangan Verlag'']. Publisher's Website, Retrieved 21 January 2011.</ref>
In the last decade he was involved in resident action groups and was elected chairman of the ''Ultimo Precinct Committee''<ref>[http://www.gangart.com/ultimo/reports/040427_chairman.html ''Precinct Chairman’s Report 2003/2004'']. Website of the Ultimo Society, Retrieved 11 January 2011.</ref> in Sydney. He is founder of the forum for [[Austrians Abroad]] (2004) and since 2007 has been on the board of directors of the ''World Federation of Austrians Abroad (AÖWB)''.<ref>In: Helmut Tomitz: ''Österreich(er) im Ausland – quo vadis?'' Multikulturalismus und Migration zu Beginn des 21. Jahrhunderts: Eine Identitäts-Analyse der Persistenz kultureller Eigenheiten österreichischer Auslandsemigranten, Graz 2010.</ref> He was also convenor of ''Free Beach Action NSW'',<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2008/12/27/1229998790353.html ''One man's nakedness ambition'']. Website of the Sydney Morning Herald. Retrieved 11 January 2011.</ref> a lobby group for [[naturism]] in [[New South Wales]].
== Illness == [[File:Parkins(on)line.png|thumb|Gerald Ganglbauer's ''PON (Parkinsonline, the friendly support group)'']] In 2006 he was diagnosed with early onset Parkinson's disease, which forced him into retirement in 2007, before the age of 50.<ref>[http://www.gangart.com/home/ ''I retired from the rat race in 2007'']. Website of Gerald Ganglbauer. Retrieved 11 January 2011.</ref> With this dramatic change in his life, he became active in Parkinson's [[support groups]] in Austria (''Parkinson Selbsthilfe Steiermark'') and New South Wales (''Parkinson's NSW Inc.'') and, despite his illness was re-elected AÖWB director in 2010.<ref>Günter Düriegl: ''Der Weltbund tagte in Eisenstadt.'' In: [http://www.weltbund.at/rot_weiss_rot_archiv.asp ROTWEISSROT], No. 4, 2010, p. 9.</ref> Together with Viennese neurologist Dr Wilibald Gerschlager he started the Austrian Parkinson's forum ''Parkinsonberatung'' and ran it from June 2007 to January 2011, and, after that, a Facebook page and a Twitter microblog for the umbrella organisation ''Parkinson Selbsthilfe Österreich''. On [[Skype]] he introduced ''Parkinsonline'' [[Instant messaging|IM groups]] in August 2010.<ref>''Hilfe auch online.'' In: [http://www.woche.at/ Die Woche], 25 August 2010, p. 14, and ''Die Krankheit, die sich in mein Leben schlich.'' In: [http://www.grazer.at/ Der Grazer], 29 August 2010, p. 36/37.</ref> In Sydney he convened an inner city support group,<ref>[http://www.ultimo.org.au/ ''Convenor, Ultimo Support Group'']. Website of the Ultimo Support Group. Retrieved 11 January 2011.</ref> moved back to Austria in 2013, and became first elected president of Austrian Parkinson's association PON,<ref>[http://www.parkinsonline.info/ ''President, Parkinsonline Austria'']. PON (Parkinsonline) Team. Retrieved 28 March 2014.</ref> in 2014. He is also a contributing author to Dr Gerschlager's book on Parkinson's disease.<ref>Willibald Gerschlager: Parkinson. Maudrich, Vienna 2009, {{ISBN|978-3-85175-907-5}}.</ref>
== Publications ==
=== English-language publications === * ''Evading the jaws of giants, Independent publishing in Austria.'' Editions Review, Sydney and Melbourne 1990. * ''Multicultural Publishing: How hard is it to do in Australia?'' Carnivale Literary Festival, Sydney 2001. * ''Publishing My Way.'' National Young Writers Festival, Newcastle 2002. * ''Cyberspace (Die Verbundenheit der Differenz: Kommunikation ohne Grenzen).'' TUAC, Vienna 2003. * ''Virtual Communities (Virtuelle Gemeinschaften).'' IRICS, Vienna 2005. * ''World ID – no place is home anymore'' "V" Identities, Bregenz 2011.
=== German-language publications === * ''Stop-Over (Ich bin eine Reise).'' Die Rampe XVIII.2, Linz 1992. * ''Halbe Österreicher.'' ROTWEISSROT, Vienna 1996. * ''Der ganz langsame Abstieg.'' In: Willibald Gerschlager: ''Parkinson. Ursachen, Diagnose, Verlauf und Therapieoptionen.'' Maudrich, Vienna 2009. * ''Ich bin eine Reise. Eine autobiografische Montage über Leben, Liebe, Leidenschaft – und Parkinson.'' Gangan, Stattegg-Ursprung 2014. * ''Einunddreißig. Ein Mann, 30 Frauen, Parkinson-Medikamente und eine Liebesgeschichte.'' Gangan, Stattegg-Ursprung 2015. * ''Geografie der Liebe. Stationen, Begegnungen, Transit Zonen, Life and Times: die Generation der Baby-Boomer.'' Gangan, Stattegg-Ursprung 2016.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.austlit.edu.au/run?ex=ShowAgent&agentId=A42- AustLit – The Australian Literature Resource] * [http://www.ganglbauer.info Gerald Ganglbauer] * [http://www.gangan.com Gangan Verlag] * [http://www.gangway.net Gangway Literary Magazine] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11354608@N04/ Photo Portfolio] * [http://www.parkinsonberatung.at Parkinsonberatung] * [http://www.parkinsonline.info Parkins(on)line]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Albert Hadley Cantril, Jr. | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 16 June 1906 | birth_place = [[Hyrum, Utah]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1969|5|28|1906|6|16}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = [[Dartmouth College]]
[[Harvard University]] | employer = | occupation = Psychologist, researcher | party = | spouse = Mavis L. Cantril | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Albert Hadley Cantril, Jr.''' (16 June 1906 – 28 May 1969) was a [[Princeton University]] [[psychologist]] who expanded the scope of the field. Cantril made "major contributions in psychology of propaganda; public opinion research; applications of psychology and psychological research to national policy, international understanding, and communication; developmental psychology; psychology of social movements; measurement and scaling; humanistic psychology; the psychology of perception; and, basic to all of them, the analysis of human behavior from the transactional point of view." His influence is felt in education, law, philosophy, politics and psychiatry. "Hadley Cantril, Princeton psychologist, is representative of most quantitative scholars of social influence who, while holding their political commitments close to the vest, nevertheless saw themselves clearly in the ranks of reformers loosely attached to the [[progressive movement]]…. Focus on social process and a psychological view of people put the academic scientists of society in a frame of mind to assume the [[polis]] languished chiefly because of inaction on the part of enlightened administrators."{{rp|74}} ==Biography== Cantril was born in [[Hyrum, Utah]] in 1906 and first studied at [[Dartmouth College]], graduating [[Bachelor of Science]] in 1928. He did graduate study in Munich and Berlin, then studied at [[Harvard]] graduating with [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in [[psychology]] in 1931. He was hired as an instructor by Dartmouth and joined the [[Princeton University]] faculty in 1936. The next year he became president of the [[Institute for Propaganda Analysis]] and one of the founding editors of ''[[Public Opinion Quarterly]]''. Later be became chairman of the [[Princeton University Department of Psychology]]. F. P. Kilpatrick (November 1969) "Hadley Cantril – The Transactional Point of View", [[Journal of Individual Psychology]] 25: 219–25, reprinted as Epilogue, pages 229–34, in Albert H. Cantril, editor (1988) ''Psychology, Humanism and Scientific Inquiry'', [[Transaction Books]] {{ISBN|0-88738-176-6}} Cantril was a member of the [[Radio Project|Princeton Radio Research Project]]. The Project looked at the reaction to Orson Welles' [[The War of the Worlds]] and published a study accenting the public's disturbance.Hadley Cantril, Hazel Gaudet, and [[Herta Herzog]] (1940) ''The Invasion from Mars: A Study in the Psychology of Panic: with the Complete Script of the Famous Orson Welles Broadcast'', [[Princeton University Press]] In 1940 he served as a consultant to the [[Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs]].{{cite book |title=Investigation of un-American propaganda activities in the United States|year=1940|pages=3244|quote= and a special consultant for the Office of the Coordinator of Inter- American Affairs|publisher=United States Government Printing Office}} Cantril's later psychological work included collaboration with [[Adelbert Ames, Jr.]] developing a [[transactional analysis|transactional]] method for studying human perception, as well as other research in [[humanistic psychology]].{{rp|389–90}} ==Public opinion research== Though trained as a psychologist, Cantril's most important work concerned the then-new topic of [[public opinion]] research. Influenced initially by the success of [[George Gallup]] and [[Elmo Roper]] during the [[1936 presidential election]], Cantril sought to apply their systematic [[opinion poll|poll]]ing technique to academic [[social psychology]].{{rp|388}} While Cantril was department chairman he became a [[presidential advisor]]:
Cantril's small-scale program at Princeton became more extensive in September 1940 when [[Nelson Rockefeller]], [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|FDR]]'s Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, asked the Princeton psychologist to "set up mechanisms which would gauge public opinion in [[Latin America]]." In cooperation with [[George Gallup|Gallup]], and with funds from the [[FEMA|Office of Emergency Management]], Cantril established an ostensibly independent research organization, American Social Surveys. He recruited his friend [[Leonard Doob]], and another researcher [[Lloyd A. Free|Lloyd Free]], to analyse Nazi propaganda coming into Latin America. Through Rockefeller's office, the results of Cantril's program were brought to the attention of FDR. The president asked Cantril to monitor public sentiment on avoiding war verses aiding Britain. Cantril duely kept tabs on views about aiding England and on the public's willingness to change U.S. neutrality laws in favor of Britain.J. Michael Sproule (1997) ''Propaganda and Democracy'', page 184, [[Cambridge University Press]] {{ISBN|0-521-47022-6}}
In 1942 Cantril conducted a small-sample survey of [[Vichy France|Vichy]] officials in Morocco, prior to [[Operation Torch]], that revealed the intensity of the anti-British sentiment of the French forces there. This information influenced the disposition of forces during the operation, with American troops landing near Casablanca and mixed forces at Oran and Algiers.John Gray Geer (2004) ''Public opinion and polling around the world: a historical encyclopedia'', Volume 1, [[ABC-CLIO]] {{ISBN|9781576079119}} {{rp|389}}{{cite book |title=Attitudes and Opinions |author=Stuart Oskamp, P. Wesley Schultz |publisher=Routledge |year=2005 |isbn=0-8058-4769-3 |pages=314}} In 1955 he and Lloyd Free founded the Institute for International Social Research (IISR). The IISR was often asked by United States government agencies to conduct small-sample public opinion polls in foreign countries."Worldwide Propaganda Network Built by the C.I.A." ''New York Times'', December 26, 1976 Notably, Cantril and Free conducted a poll of Cuba during 1960 demonstrating great support for [[Fidel Castro]], which was overlooked during the [[United States presidential transition|presidential transition]] between Eisenhower and [[John F. Kennedy|Kennedy]] and read only after the [[Bay of Pigs Invasion]] fiasco."Lloyd A. Free, 88, is dead; Revealed Political Paradox", [[New York Times]], November 14, 1996. Cantril's most-cited work is ''The Pattern of Human Concerns,'' notable for the development of the [[self-anchoring scale]] (also known as "Cantril's Ladder").[http://www.gallup.com/poll/122453/understanding-gallup-uses-cantril-scale.aspx Understanding How Gallup uses the Cantril Scale] from [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] Cantril and Free also first discovered the paradox that American voters tend to oppose "big government" in general while supporting many specific liberal [[Social programs in the United States|social program]]s. During the late 1950s, Cantril served on the International Objectives and Strategies panel of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund's [[Special Studies Project]].{{cite book |title=Prospect for America: The Rockefeller Panel Reports |year=1961 |publisher=Doubleday}} ==Works== * 1934: ''Social Psychology of Everyday Life'' * 1935:(with [[Gordon Allport]]) [https://archive.org/details/psychologyofradi00hadl Psychology of Radio] from [[Internet Archive]] * 1939: ''Industrial Conflict: a Psychological Interpretation'', * 1940: ''The Invasion from Mars, a Study in the Psychology of Panic'' * 1940: ''America Faces the War, a Study in Public Opinion'' * 1941: [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=inu.32000002806372;view=1up;seq=9 Psychology of Social Movements] from [[HathiTrust]] * 1944: [https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.275054 Gauging Public Opinion], Princeton University Press, via Internet Archive * 1947: (with [[Muzafer Sherif]]) [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/004572990 Psychology of ego-involvements : social attitudes & identifications] via HathiTrust * 1950: ''The "Why" of Man's Experience'', 1950 * 1950: ''Tensions that cause wars (a report for UNESCO)'', 1950 * 1951: (with Mildred Strunk) ''Public Opinion, 1935–1946'', massive compilation of many public opinion polls from the USA; also some polls from Europe and Canada [https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.128827 online] * 1953: (with William Buchanan) ''How Nations See Each Other, a study in public opinion'' * 1954: (with William H. Ittelson) ''Perception: a Transactional Approach'' * 1956: ''On Understanding the French Left'' * 1958: [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001748463 Faith, Hope, and Heresy: the Psychology of the Protest Voter] via HathiTrust * 1958: [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/007040403 Politics of Despair] via HathiTrust * 1960: ''Reflections on the Human Venture'' * 1960: ''Soviet Leaders and Mastery over Man'' * 1961: ''Human Nature and Political Systems'' * 1965: ''Pattern of Human Concerns'' * 1967: (with [[L. A. Free]]) ''Political beliefs of Americans; a study of public opinion'' * 1967: ''The Human Dimension: Experiences in Policy Research'' * 1988: (Albert H. Cantril, editor) ''Psychology, Humanism, and Scientific Inquiry: the Selected Essays of Hadley Cantril'' ==References== {{reflist|2}} * [https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/hadley-cantril/ Hadley Cantril] from [[Roper Center for Public Opinion Research]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cantril, Hadley}} [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Dartmouth College alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Princeton University faculty]] [[Category:Humanistic psychologists]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Pollsters]] [[Category:People from Hyrum, Utah]]

{{About|the politician|the footballer|Hassan Habibi (footballer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Hassan Habibi |image = Hassan Habibi 1980.jpg |imagesize = 220px |smallimage = |caption = Habibi in 1980 |order = [[Vice President of Iran|First Vice President of Iran]] |term_start = 1 September 1989 |term_end = 11 September 2001 |president = [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]
[[Mohammad Khatami]] |predecessor = ''Office established'' |successor = [[Mohammad-Reza Aref]] |order2 = [[Ministry of Justice (Iran)|Minister of Justice]] |term_start2 = 9 March 1985 |term_end2 = 1 September 1989 |president2 = [[Ali Khamenei]] |primeminister2 = [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] |predecessor2 = Mohammad Asghari |successor2 = [[Esmail Shooshtari]] |office3 = [[Parliament of Iran|Member of the Parliament of Iran]] |constituency3 = [[Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr (electoral district)|Tehran, Rey and Shemiranat]] |term_start3 = 28 May 1980 |term_end3 = 28 May 1984 |majority3 = 1,552,478 (72.7%) |order4 = [[Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)|Minister of Culture and Higher Education]] |term_start4 = 1 October 1979 |term_end4 = 6 November 1979 |primeminister4 = [[Mehdi Bazargan]] |predecessor4 = [[Ali Shariatmadari]] |successor4 = Hassan Arefi |birth_name = Hassan Ebrahim Habibi |birth_date = {{Birth date|1937|01|29|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|01|31|1937|01|29|df=y}} |death_place = Tehran, Iran |otherparty = |party = {{plainlist| *[[Executives of Construction Party]] {{small|(1996–2013)}} *[[Islamic Republican Party]] {{small|(1979–1987)}} *[[Freedom Movement of Iran|Freedom Movement]] {{small|(1966–1979)}}}} |awards = [[File:Independence Ribbon Bar (I.R.Iran).svg|30px]] [[Order of Independence (Iran)|Excellent Order of Independence]]{{cite news|url=http://rc.majlis.ir/fa/law/show/117746|work=[[Iranian Parliament]]|script-title=fa:اعطای نشان عالی استقلال به آقای حسن حبیبی معاون اول رئیس جمهور|trans-title=Endowing the Excellent Order of Independence to Mr. Hassan Habibi, First Vice President|language=Persian|date=26 July 1997|access-date=15 April 2016}}
[[File:Ribbon of Knowledge.png|30px]] [[Order of Knowledge]] (1st class){{cite news|url=http://www.tasnimnews.com/fa/news/1392/06/02/122731/%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%85%DB%8C-%D9%88-%D8%A7%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF%DB%8C-%D9%86%DA%98%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%A8%D9%87-%DA%86%D9%87-%DA%A9%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%B1%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%84|work=[[Tasnim News Agency]]|script-title=fa:نشان‌های دولتی در روزهای پایانی خاتمی و احمدی‌نژاد به چه‌کسانی رسید؟ |trans-title=|language=Persian|date=24 August 2013|access-date=15 April 2016}} |spouse = Shafigheh Rahideh{{cite web|url=http://www.khodnevis.org/persian/permalink/11739.html|script-title=fa:همسران حکومتی؛ از حاشیه تا متن|author=Dana Dabir|date=7 March 2011|work=Khodnevis|language=Persian|trans-title=Governmental spouses; from the margin to the text|accessdate=7 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120804204617/http://www.khodnevis.org/persian/permalink/11739.html|archivedate=4 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} |children = |profession = |religion = [[Islam]] |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Hassan Ebrahim Habibi''' (29 January 1937 – 31 January 2013) was an Iranian politician, lawyer, scholar and the first [[Vice President of Iran|vice president]] from 1989 until 2001 under Presidents [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] and [[Mohammad Khatami]]. He was also a member of the [[High Council of Cultural Revolution]] and head of [[Academy of Persian Language and Literature]] from 2004 until his death in 2013. ==Early life and education== Habibi was born on 29 January 1937. He studied sociology in France.{{cite journal|last=Chehabi|first=H. E.|title=Religion and Politics in Iran: How Theocratic Is the Islamic Republic?|journal=Daedalus|date=Summer 1991|volume=120|issue=3|pages=69–91|jstor=20025388 .}}{{cite journal|last=Randjbar-Daemi|first=Siavush|title=Building the Islamic State: The Draft Constitution of 1979 Reconsidered|journal=Iranian Studies|year=2013|volume=46|issue=4|pages=641–663|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00210862.2013.784519|accessdate=21 August 2013|doi=10.1080/00210862.2013.784519}} He held a PhD in law and sociology. When he was a university student he visited [[Khomeini]] while the latter was in exile.{{cite book|title=Iran: A Revolutionary Republic in Transition|publisher=Institute for Security Studies European Union|location=Paris|isbn=978-92-9198-198-4|url=http://www.ab.gov.tr/files/ardb/evt/1_avrupa_birligi/1_9_politikalar/1_9_8_dis_politika/Iran_A_revolutionary_republic_in_transition.pdf|author=Paola Rivetti|editor=Rouzbeh Parsi|accessdate=27 July 2013|format=Chaillot Papers|chapter=Islamic Republic: Shaping Iran's politics through the campus|date=February 2012}} ==Career== Habibi was tasked by [[Ayatollah Khomenei]] to draft the prospective constitution of Iran when the latter was in exile in [[Paris]].{{cite journal|last=Akhavi|first=Shahrough|title=The Thought and Role of Ayatollah Hossein'ali Montazeri in the Politics of Post-1979 Iran|journal=Iranian Studies|year=2008|volume=41|issue=5|pages=645–666|doi=10.1080/00210860802518301|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00210860802518301|accessdate=19 August 2013}} His version was heavily modified due to criticisms and the final text was approved by the election in November 1979. Following [[Iranian Revolution|the Iranian revolution]], Habibi was named public spokesman for [[Revolutionary council of Islamic revolution of Iran|the revolutionary council]].{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Barry|title=Paved with Good Intentions|year=1980|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New York|page=284|url=http://www.gloria-center.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Paved-with-Good-Intentions-final.pdf}} He was among the main architects of the first draft of [[Politics of Iran|Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran]], which was later passed for more discussion to an elected [[Assembly of Experts for Constitution]]. The assembly made significant changes in the original draft, e.g. by introducing the new position of "leader of the Islamic Republic" based on [[Khomeini]]'s concept of [[Guardianship of the Islamic Jurists]], which gave almost unlimited power to the clergy. The modified version was approved in a popular referendum in 1979. In the 1980 presidential election, Habibi run for office, but received only ten percent of the vote against Banisadr's seventy percent.{{cite journal|last=Rouleau|first=Eric|title=Khomenei's Iran|journal=Foreign Affairs|year=1980|volume=59|issue=1|url=http://ha6uq4xy8k.scholar.serialssolutions.com/?sid=google&auinit=E&aulast=Rouleau&atitle=Khomeini%27s+Iran&title=Foreign+affairs+(New+York,+N.Y.)&volume=59&date=1980&spage=1&issn=0015-7120|accessdate=5 August 2013}} Habibi was backed by [[Mohammad Beheshti]] in the election process. In the same year he won a parliamentary seat, being a representative of [[Islamic Republican Party|the Islamic Republican Party]].{{cite book|title=Parliamentary Politics in Revolutionary Iran: The Institutionalization of Factional Politics|year=1996|publisher=University Press of Florida|location=Gainesville, FL|page=69|url=https://www.questia.com/read/94909658/parliamentary-politics-in-revolutionary-iran-the|author=Bahman Baktiari}} {{Subscription required|via=Questia}} Habibi served as the minister of justice under [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi|Prime Minister Mousavi]]. He was first vice president of Iran from 1989 to 2001, eight years under [[Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani|President Rafsanjani]] and then four years under [[Mohammad Khatami|President Khatami]].{{cite news|title=Hassan Ebrahim Habibi, Iranian scholar & former VP passes away|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2013/02/01/286749/iran-former-vice-president-pass-away-habibi-hassan-scholar-persian-language/|accessdate=2 February 2013|newspaper=PressTV|date=1 February 2013}} He was replaced by [[Mohammad Reza Aref]] in the post in Khatami's second term. He was also head of the Academy of Persian Language and Literature{{cite news|title=Iranologists condemn deliberate distortion of Persian Gulf's name|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/04/dec/1206.html|accessdate=6 August 2013|newspaper=Payvand|date=24 December 2004}} and a member of [[Expediency Council|the Expediency Council]]. ==Death== Habibi died on 31 January 2013. He was buried at the mausoleum of Imam Khomeini in Tehran on 1 February.{{cite news|title=Iran's former first vice president laid to rest|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/politics/105310-irans-former-first-vice-president-laid-to-rest|accessdate=6 August 2013|newspaper=Tehran Times|date=1 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005022529/http://www.tehrantimes.com/politics/105310-irans-former-first-vice-president-laid-to-rest|archivedate=5 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} The funeral service was attended by leading Iranian political figures, including President [[Mahmoud Ahmedinejad|Ahmedinejad]]. ==Work== Habibi is the author of several books, including ''God'' (1981), ''Society, Culture, Politics'' (1984), ''Islam and the Crisis of Our Time'' (1984), ''In the Mirror Of Rights: Views Of International Rights, Comparative Rights And Sociology'' (1988), ''Seeking the Roots'' (editing & translation) (1994), ''Casework of An Ages Student'' (1997), ''One Word Out Of Thousands'' (2 vol.) (1998-2001) and ''General International Rights'' (2 vol.) (2003).{{cite web|title=Dr. Hassan Habibi|url=http://www.eveagency.net/authers5.htm|publisher=Eve Literary Agency|accessdate=2 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130221105948/http://www.eveagency.net/authers5.htm|archivedate=21 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=''Office established''}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Vice President of Iran|First Vice President of Iran]]|years=1989–2001}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mohammad-Reza Aref]]}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jalaleddin Farsi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Islamic Republican Party]] nominee for [[President of Iran]]|years=[[Iranian presidential election, 1980|1980]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mohammad-Ali Rajaei]]}} {{s-end}} {{First Vice Presidents of Iran}} {{Khatami cabinet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Habibi, Hassan}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Deputies of Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr]] [[Category:First Vice Presidents of Iran]] [[Category:Government ministers of Iran]] [[Category:Freedom Movement of Iran politicians]] [[Category:Executives of Construction Party politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Expediency Discernment Council]] [[Category:Iranian presidential candidates, 1980]] [[Category:Members of the Academy of Persian Language and Literature]] [[Category:People of the Iranian Revolution]] [[Category:Members of the 1st Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Recipients of the Excellent Order of Independence]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Knowledge]] [[Category:Islamic Republican Party politicians]] [[Category:Iranian government spokesmen]] [[Category:Members of the Guardian Council]]

[[Image:Menagerie.amburgh.portrait.jpg|286px|right|Isaac Van Amburgh Biographical Sketch, ca. 1860]]
'''Isaac A. Van Amburgh''' (1808–1865) was an American [[animal trainer]] who developed the first trained wild animal act in modern times.<ref name="Culhane pg. 20">Culhane, John. ''The American Circus,'' Henry Holt and Company, Inc., 1990., pg. 20</ref> By introducing jungle acts into the circus, Van Amburgh paved the way for combining [[menagerie]]s with [[circus|circuses.]] After that, menageries began using equestrian and [[clown]] performances in circus rings. Gradually the distinction between circus and menagerie faded.<ref name="Culhane pg. 17">Culhane, John. ''The American Circus,'' Henry Holt and Company, Inc., 1990., pg. 17</ref>
From the humble beginning of cage-cleaner in the Zoological Institute of New York, Van Amburgh quickly gained notoriety for his acts of daring, for example placing his bare arm and even head inside the jaws of a wild cat.<ref name="History">''History Magazine,'' "Step Right Up," October/November 2001 issue http://www.history-magazine.com/circuses.html.</ref> Also known for his domineering attitude toward his animals, he earned the title “The Lion King.”<ref name="Culhane pg. 17" />
Despite the disapproval of some for his brutal treatment of animals, Van Amburgh remained very popular and successful, beginning his own menagerie which he took to Europe. He died a wealthy man, and his name continued to be used in the circus world for more than a century after.<ref name="Culhane pg. 149">Culhane, John. ''The American Circus,'' Henry Holt and Company, Inc., 1990., pg. 149</ref>
==Early Life and Beginnings of Career== Isaac A. Van Amburgh (a name adopted by his American Indian grandfather) was born on May 26, 1808 in [[Fishkill (town), New York|Fishkill, New York.]]<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /> Legend dictates that while reading the Bible, young Isaac came upon the tale of [[Book of Daniel|Daniel]] in the lion’s den, and, from then on, was determined to be a lion tamer.<ref name="Rose">Johnson, William M., ''The Rose-Tinted Menagerie'' (http://www.iridescent-publishing.com/rtm/ch1p3.htm).</ref> He found his start in the Zoological Institute of New York.
===Zoological Institute of New York===
At nineteen, Isaac left his home in [[Peekskill, New York]] to look for a job in neighboring [[North Salem, New York|North Salem.]]<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /> There he found a job as a cage cleaner in the Zoological Institute of New York.<ref name="Bunyan">{{Harvtxt|Bunyan|1999}}</ref>
Despite its lofty-sounding name, the Zoological Institute was not a zoo at all, but rather a tiny traveling menagerie.<ref name="Bunyan" /><ref name="Culhane pg. 16" /> In a period of time when amusement was regarded with suspicion, it was from its name that this show got its value.<ref name="Culhane pg. 16">Culhane, John. ''The American Circus,'' Henry Holt and Company, Inc., 1990., pg. 16</ref>
Although he started out as a "cage boy," Isaac showed an aptitude for training the wild animals whose cages he cleaned.<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /> One of the owners of the Zoological Institute, Titus, was a dealer in wild animals. So he appreciated the novelty of trained wild animals, recognizing that "novelty plus publicity meant money."<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" />
June, Titus, and Angevine distributed posters by the thousands. They put Isaac in costume – a Roman toga, in reference to the gladiators of ancient Rome's [[Circus Maximus]]. In the winter, Van Amburgh trained his wild animals in the barns of New York's upper Westchester and the lower Putnam counties. The next year, 1821, the Van Amburgh Menagerie hit New York City.
==The Lion King==
[[Image:Menagerie.amburgh.1838.jpg|thumb|alt=Van Amburgh stands with his foot on a lion.|Isaac van Amburgh (1808–1865) by T. C. Wilson 1838 in National Portrait Gallery, London''.]]
In 1833, at age twenty-two, Isaac A. Van Amburgh entered a cage of wild cats at the Zoological Institute.<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /> In the cage were a lion, a lioness, leopard, leopardess, black-maned Cape lion, and a panther.<ref name="Virginia">#“Circus in America” © to Lavahn G. Hoh and the University of Virginia, 2004 http://www.circusinamerica.org/public/timelines?date1=1825&date2=1871</ref> From the Richmond Hill Theatre, New York, Van Amburgh astonished the country.<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /><ref name="Virginia" /><ref name="Michigan">Central Michigan University, Mount Pleasant, Mich. 48859, January 13, 2011, http://clarke.cmich.edu/resource_tab/information_and_exhibits/rides_and_spangles_michigan_circuses_and_carnivals/lion_tamers.html</ref> In the words of his biographer, "The effect of his power was instantaneous. The Lion halted and stood transfixed. The Tiger crouched. The Panther with a suppressed growl of rage sprang back, while the Leopard receded gradually from its master. The spectators were overwhelmed with wonder .... Then came the most effective tableaux of all. Van Amburgh with his strong will bade them come to him while he reclined in the back of the cage – the proud King of animal creation."<ref name="Ferguson">Ferguson, O. J. ''Biographical Sketch of I. A. Van Amburgh.'' Booth & Co., 1865.</ref>
Van Amburgh did more than just enter the cage. [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]] described a menagerie he saw on September 4, 1828, near North Adams, Massachusetts: “A man put his arm and head into the lion’s mouth, – all the spectators looking on so attentively that a breath could not be heard. That was impressive, – its effect on a thousand persons, – more than the thing itself.”<ref name="Hawthorne">Hawthorne, Nathaniel. Passages from the American Note-Books of Nathaniel Hawthorne. Boston: Houghton, Mifflin, 1898. Entry for September 4, 1838.</ref> As Van Amburgh was one of the few performers of the time to perform this way, Hawthorne probably saw{{clarify|date=September 2018|reason=Is there some reason to think that he didn't seenit in person? Especially given such a specific description? Would he sometimes write as if he was there about 2nd hand experiences? Or does the sentence mean saw as in met with afterwards?}} Van Amburgh.<ref name="Culhane pg. 21">Culhane, John. ''The American Circus,'' Henry Holt and Company, Inc., 1990., pg. 21.</ref> In fact, Van Amburgh is usually credited with being the first man ever to put his head into the mouth of a lion.<ref name="Rose" /> In July 7, 1838, the [[New York Mirror]] also described how Van Amburgh’s “fearless acts of placing his bare arm moist with blood, in the lion’s mouth and thrusting his head into the distended jaws of the tiger” were watched with keen interest.<ref name="Virginia" />
===Van Amburgh's Menagerie===
Van Amburgh, made an instant hero, discovered he now had the freedom to make his own decisions.<ref name="Rose" /> By entering lions’ dens in and out of the country, he began earning real money.<ref name="Rose" /> Featured in the “Flatfoot shows,” he was able to earn up to four hundred dollars per week.<ref name="Culhane pg. 20" /> By age twenty-three, he had his own [[travelling menagerie]], and by the mid-1840s his was the largest traveling show in England.<ref name="Rose" /> In 1861, it was one of America’s eleven big traveling shows.<ref name="Culhane pg. 66">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 66.</ref>
Even after the 1868 fire that killed Van Amburgh’s animals and destroyed other circus artifacts, the potent name of Van Amburgh continued to be used by circuses until 1922.<ref name="Culhane pg. 97">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 97.</ref><ref name="Culhane pg. 13">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 13.</ref>
===London and Queen Victoria===
[[Image:Landseer.amburgh.jpg|thumb|''Isaac van Amburgh with his Animals'' by Sir [[Edwin Henry Landseer]] ]]
In the late 1830s, Van Amburgh took his act to England and Europe for several years.<ref name="Virginia" /><ref name="Thayer">Thayer, Stuart. ‘‘American Circus Anthology, Essays of the Early Years,’’ arranged and edited by [[William L. Slout]]. Copyright © 2005 by Stuart Thayer and William L. Slout.</ref> He made his debut in London at Astley’s on August 27, 1838, and his said to have made £300 per week there.<ref name="Culhane pg. 24">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 24.</ref>
While in England, Van Amburgh performed for [[Queen Victoria]] and [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]] in 1844.<ref name="Culhane pg. 55">Culhane, John, 1990 The American Circus, pg. 55.</ref> The former took special interest in him. In fact, the Queen commissioned artist [[Edwin Henry Landseer|Edwin Landseer]] to paint a portrait of Van Amburgh and his cats.<ref name="Virginia" /> Upon its completion, the painting was exhibited at the Royal Academy, an impressive honor for the time.<ref name="Culhane pg. 24" />
In 1839, Queen Victoria traveled six times in as many months solely to watch Van Amburgh perform at [[Drury Lane]].<ref name="Culhane pg. 24" /><ref name="Culhane pg. 39">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 39.</ref> She even remained after one evening’s performance in order to watch his feeding the cats.<ref name="Culhane pg. 39" /> Even before his 1838 European debut, Van Amburgh was one of America’s most celebrated characters. But after such special royal favor, Van Amburgh “became a figure that even the American upper crust could admit to appreciating.”<ref name="Culhane pg. 39" /> He was the first major American wild animal trainer to achieve such an international celebrity status.<ref name="Michigan" />
==Criticisms==
[[Image:Menagerie.amburgh.lions.JPG|400px|right|Van Amburgh in the Wild Cat Cage]]
Circuses were regularly under attack in the press and at the pulpit as “traveling death” and “moral ruin.” <ref name="Culhane pg. 31">Culhane, John, 1990 ‘’The American Circus,’’ pg. 31.</ref> But predecessors of Van Amburgh were less inhumane.<ref name="Thayer2">‘‘Band Wagon,’’ “The Keeper Will Enter the Cage: Early American Wild Animal Trainers,” November–December 1982.</ref> Despite his great success and popularity, Van Amburgh regularly faced criticism for the cruelty he showed to his animals.<ref name="Culhane pg. 31" /> Van Amburgh reportedly beat his animals with a crowbar.<ref name="History" /><ref name="Virginia" /> In costume, whether in loose-fitting jungle clothing or ancient Roman gladiatorial garb, Van Amburgh would bait the animals, attempting to evoke as much ferocity on their part as he could.<ref name="History" /><ref name="Rose" /> Thereupon, he would beat them into submission. “His ‘‘piece de resistance’’ was forcing the lions to ... lick his boots as the ultimate sign of his conquest and the animals’ abject subservience.”<ref name="Rose" /> Van Amburgh’s own publicity agent, Hyat Frost, reported that Van Amburgh starved his lions for three days before one of these royal command performances. They were so hungry when it came time to perform that he was forced to “lash them furiously with his whip ‘into the most abject and crouching submission.’”<ref name="Rose" />
In response to these attacks, Van Amburgh cited Bible verses to justify his touring menagerie.<ref name="History" /><ref name="Culhane pg. 31" /> He quoted [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 1:26, arguing that God had given men dominion over animals. Thus “it was a religious act for trained animals to kneel at his feet.”<ref name="Culhane pg. 31" /> He is also well-remembered for having acted out a scene from the Bible by forcing a lion and a lamb to lie down together and even inviting a child from the audience into the den.<ref name="History" /><ref name="Culhane pg. 31" />
==Death and legacy== In August 1838, the editor of the ''Age'' reported that “there have already been several cases in which lions have snapped off the heads of persons persisting in this sort of foolish experiment.”<ref name="Culhane pg. 24" /> Van Amburgh, however, was one of the few early lion tamers who died in bed. On November 29, 1865, at age fifty-four, Isaac A. Van Amburgh suffered a fatal heart attack in Philadelphia. He died a very wealthy man.<ref name="Culhane pg. 24" />
Even after Van Amburgh's death, Hyatt Frost, his manager since 1865, continued using the Van Amburgh name.<ref name="Culhane pg. 24" /> From him it was leased by the [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus|Ringling Brothers]] in 1889.<ref name="Culhane pg. 149"/>
Van Amburgh himself lived to hear his deeds put to a popular song, “The Menagerie.” Dr. W. J. Wetmore, M.D., published “Van Amburgh’s Menagerie” in 1865, which began like this:<ref name="Song">https://jscholarship.library.jhu.edu/handle/1774.2/14693 .</ref>
''Van Amburgh is the man, who goes to all the shows''
''He goes into the lion's cage, and tells you all he knows;''
''He sticks his head in the lion's mouth,and keeps it there a-while,''
''And when he pulls it out again, he greets you with a smile.''
chorus:
''The elephant now moves round, the music begins to play.''
''Them boys around the monkey’s cage had better keep away”
==See also== * [[Lion taming]]

{{for|his son, a New South Wales colonial politician|James Oatley (New South Wales politician)}} {{for|the Australian cricketer|James Oatley (cricketer)}} '''James Oatley Snr''' (c. 1769–1839) was a [[Great Britain|British]]-born [[History of Australia (1788–1850)|colonial Australian]] watch and clock maker and one-time [[convict]]. Oatley, allegedly from [[Stafford]] and aged 44, was sentenced to [[penal transportation]] for life at [[Hampshire]] [[Assizes]] on 7 March 1814. James had a number of convictions, dating back to 1806, when he had stolen one ton of cheese. He was sent to Australia for stealing shirts and bedding: ''Hampshire Chronicle'' Monday 14 March 1814 p3 [6, 7, 8, 16]
==Life in colonial Sydney== Oatley arrived in [[Sydney, New South Wales]] on 27 January 1815 on board the ''Marquis of Wellington'' [7, 10]. On 25 October 1821, he was given a conditional pardon. In this record, James is mentioned as a "native of Warwickshire", and a physical description is also provided; he is described as being pale, with dark brown hair, grey eyes, 5'5", and "stout" (with the remainder of the instrument of pardon being difficult to read) [7, 8, 10].
Oatley was awarded several land grants; in 1831 and on 30 October 1832, 24 December 1833, 23 January 1834, and 27 July 1835. Areas covered by these land grants include Snugborough (in the vicinity of the modern Moorefields Road, [[Kingsgrove, New South Wales|Kingsgrove]]), which he farmed, and Needwood Forest (now [[Hurstville Grove, New South Wales|Hurstville Grove]]). In total, the land approximately covered is similar to that now bounded by Canterbury Road, [[Belmore, New South Wales|Belmore]], to the north, King George Road to the west, Kingsgrove Road to the east, and the [[Georges River]] to the south [15].
==Death== James Oatley died on 9 October 1839. His death notice in the ''Sydney Monitor'' gives his age as 72 years; the Parish record of his burial gives James' age as 70 years. James was buried on his property, ''Snugborough'' [3, 4, 5, 16].
==Legacy== Oatley and his family's legacy has been reflected via geography. In 1903, the [[southern Sydney]] suburb of [[Oatley]] was named after the family. Prior to that, the area west of the railway line was known as New Oatley's, which was a sub-district of Hurstville, and Oatley Platform; east of the railway line was known as Oatley's, which was a sub-district of Kogarah. In 1905, Frederick Street, Oatley, named after Frederick Stokes Oatley, was constructed as the main street of the new suburb [12].
Oatley Street, [[Woollahra, New South Wales|Woollahra]], lying between Ocean Street and Edgecliffe Street, existed in the 1850s and early 1860s. Frederick Stokes Oatley resided between Ocean Street and Oatley Street, Woollahra [12].
Oatley Lane, Oatley Street, and Oatley Road, all of which were named after James Oatley Jnr, existed in East Sydney. Oatley Road extended into [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]]. A remnant of Oatley Road still exists in Paddington, running beside the [[Victoria Barracks, Sydney|Victoria Barracks]] [12, 13].
The original Oatley land between Moorefields Road and the railway line through Kingsgrove Station remained largely as open paddocks until it was subdivided for housing and industry in the early 1970s. A street off Kingsgrove Road was named after James Oatley. Just north of Moorefields Road are Robert Street and Eleanor Avenue [13].
==Personal life== The personal life of James Oatley was well documented in the 1825 Muster of New South Wales [2] and in his will [1] [see Talk]. Oatley married twice. In England, he married Sarah Bennett [see Talk]. Little is known about this marriage. James than had a de facto relationship with Mary Stokes, his housekeeper [2]. Mary was the mother of his three sons, James Stokes Jnr [1], Frederick Stokes [1] and George (1820–1821) shown as James' children in the 1825 Muster [2, 3, 4, 5] and each described in James' will as "my adopted son" [1]. Mary arrived in Sydney on 8 June 1815 on board the ''Northampton'', with her son, then called James [but later renamed Robert], born during the voyage [14]. The 1825 muster clearly indicates that Robert was Mary's child, but not James' child [2]. Robert was described as "an adopted child" in James' will [1]. After Mary's death, Oatley married Mary Ann Bogg in 1833 [1, 3, 4].
===Children=== *'''Marianne/Marion Oatley''' (c1808-22 March 1866): died as Mrs Borrett [New South Wales Marriage Index; New South Wales Death Index; death notice [ [[Sydney Morning Herald]] 23 March 1866] [3, 4, 5, 16] [see Talk]. *'''[[James Oatley (New South Wales politician)|James Oatley]]''' (1817–1878) was a coach builder and engineer by trade [3, 4]. James Stokes Oatley Jnr assumed responsibiility for running the family farm after Oatley Snr's death [11]. The farm was later sold and James became an innkeeper (also described as licensee and victualler) [12] until he entered the [[Parliament of New South Wales|NSW Parliament]] [12] as a Member of the [[New South Wales Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]] in 1868.<ref>http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/ec78138918334ce3ca256ea200077f5d/596805948a5d5832ca256e4c0019ed14!OpenDocument</ref><ref>http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-pa-HTTP%253A%252F%252FWWW2.PHOTOSAU.COM%252FCITYOFSYDNEY%252FSCRIPTS%252FEXTSEARCH.ASP%253FSEARCHTERM%253D005736</ref> James married Eleanor Johnson (also known as Ellen, Helena, and Emily), with whom he had eight children. After Eleanor's death, James married Margaret Curtis, with whom he had one daughter [3, 4, 5, 16]. *'''Frederick Stokes Oatley''' (1819–1890) was a watchmaker and Inspector of Abattoirs [12, 19]. Frederick married Jane Weedon, with whom he had twelve children [3, 4, 5, 16]. James Snr gave to Frederick his watchmaking business in George Street, Sydney, and Needwood Forest [1, 12]. By the 1860s, Frederick had given up the watchmaking business; and, in 1881, he sold {{convert|300|acre|km2}} of Needwood Forest. *'''Robert Oatley''' (1815–1876) was adopted by James Oatley, but not his biological child [1, 3, 4, 5]. Robert, a cooper by trade, was born at sea ''en route'' to Sydney and was initially named James [4, 14]. After his name change and legal adoption by James Oatley, Robert was baptized about a year after his arrival in Sydney [3, 4, 5]. Robert did not marry.
===Other descendents of Oatley Snr=== *'''Gwen Ruth Oatley''' (1918–24 December 2000) was the granddaughter of James Oatley Jnr's second son, Frederick [3, 4, 5, 16]. Gwen was awarded an OAM in 1978 for services to the Australian film industry. Her obituary was published in the ''Sydney Morning Herald'' on 25 January 2001 [5]. *'''Frederick "Dudley" Weedon Oatley''' (1884–28 March 1919) was the grandson of Frederick Stokes Oatley [3, 4, 5, 16]. Frederick was a Lieutenant-Colonel in the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] and served in World War One [17, 18]. When he died, Frederick was given a funeral on 30 March 1919 with [[Military funeral|full military honours]] [5]. Frederick actually died from a massive hydatid cyst in his thoracic cavity, compressing his heart and lungs and resulting in widespread gangrene (Death Certificate) [3, 4, 5].
==See also== *[[Oatley, New South Wales]]

{{Infobox person |name=Joey Moss |image=Joey Moss.jpg |imagesize=150px |caption=Joey Moss in 2008 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|9|25}} |birth_place=[[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] |occupation=[[Locker room]] attendant for the [[Edmonton Oilers]] and the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] }} '''Joseph Neil "Joey" Moss''' (born September 25, 1963) is the [[locker room]] attendant for the [[Edmonton Oilers]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] of the [[Canadian Football League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.edmontonsun.com/2013/09/13/winnifred-stewarts-empties-for-winn-program-growing-each-year |title=Happy 50th Birthday: Joey Moss' impact on Winnifred Stewart's Empties for Winn program |first=Catherine |last=Griwkowsky |work=[[Edmonton Sun]] |date=2013-09-25 |accessdate=2018-09-26}}</ref> Born with [[Down syndrome]], Moss caught the eye of Oilers centre [[Wayne Gretzky]] in 1985, when Gretzky was dating Moss' sister, [[Vikki Moss|Vikki]]. Impressed with the dedication Moss brought to a job at an Edmonton bottle depot, Gretzky suggested to team general manager [[Glen Sather]] that the young man be given a tryout.
As the summer of 1986 came around, Gretzky was worried that Joey would lose everything he had learned with the Oilers, so Gretzky called up the equipment manager of the [[Edmonton Eskimos]], [[Dwayne Mandrusiak]], and asked him if Joey could work with them during training camp. Gretzky even offered to pay Joey's wages for the team.
Moss' career with the Oilers long outlasted Gretzky's, and his determination and passion for hockey have made him a nationwide celebrity and a major symbol of continuity within the franchise. (In 2006, during a surprising Oiler playoff run, he delayed elective surgery for a [[hernia]] in order to see the [[2006 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]] through to the finish.) His main duties with the team include cleaning, handling towels and water, and running errands for former equipment manager Lyle "Sparky" Kulchisky.
== Awards and recognition == In 2003, Moss received the NHL Alumni Association's "Seventh Man Award" in recognition of outstanding behind-the-scenes service to the league. The Joey Moss Cup, a trophy contended for by Oilers players in an annual split-squad game near the end of training camp, is named after him.
Moss' dedication to the Edmonton Eskimos and the Oilers was recognized when a mural was unveiled on October 20, 2008 on 99th Street in Edmonton. He was recognized again on November 14, 2012 with the [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alberta.ca/diamondjubileemedal.cfm |title=Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal honours |work=[[Executive Council of Alberta|Government of Alberta]] |accessdate=2012-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925211941/http://alberta.ca/diamondjubileemedal.cfm |archivedate=2013-09-25 |df= }}</ref> ([http://video.oilers.nhl.com/videocenter/console?catid=4&id=189704&lang=en Video of the Ceremony]) On May 29, 2015, Moss was inducted into the [[Alberta Sports Hall of Fame and Museum|Alberta Sports Hall of Fame]].
==Personal life== Moss was born to Lloyd Orval Moss and Sophie Frances Moss (née Murias). Joey is number twelve of thirteen children; 9 boys, 4 girls
==References== {{Reflist}}
*"Joey Moss Cup reflection of true Oiler spirit", Edmonton Journal, Sept. 10, 1999 *"Gretzky changed his life; Hockey great helped handicapped man get job", Ottawa Citizen, Jan. 27, 1990 *"Disability doesn't hold back Moss; Oilers locker-room attendant receives honour", ''Windsor Star'', Jan. 29, 2003 *"Sather took Gretzky's advice on Joey", ''Edmonton Journal'', Feb. 1, 2003 *"The Hockey Star Who Never Played", ''Reader's Digest'', Feb. 2004 *[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/ArticleNews/sports/RTGAM/20030128/wlockar/Sports/sportsBN/breakingnews-sports Oilers' attendant a celebrity], Canadian Press: January 28, 2003 *[https://www.thestar.com/sports/2013/11/22/kindness_project_wayne_gretzky_and_joey_moss_forever_changed_oilers.html Kindness Project: Wayne Gretzky and Joey Moss forever changed Oilers], The Toronto Star: November 2013
{{Edmonton Oilers}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moss, Joey}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Edmonton Oilers personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People with Down syndrome]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox baseball biography |name=Lane Adams |image=Lane Adams on September 11, 2013.jpg |image_size=240px |caption=Adams with the [[Omaha Storm Chasers]] in {{Baseball year|2013}} |position=[[Outfielder]] |team=Free agent |number= |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{birth date and age|1989|11|13}} |birth_place=[[Talihina, Oklahoma]] |debutleague = MLB |debutdate = September 1 |debutyear = 2014 |debutteam = Kansas City Royals | statyear = 2018 season |statleague = MLB | stat1label = [[Batting average]] | stat1value = .263 | stat2label = [[Home run]]s | stat2value = 7 | stat3label = [[Run batted in|Runs batted in]] | stat3value = 26 |teams= *[[Kansas City Royals]] ({{mlby|2014}}) *[[Atlanta Braves]] ({{mlby|2017}}–{{mlby|2018}}) }} '''Lane Weston Adams''' (born November 13, 1989) is an American [[professional baseball]] [[outfielder]] who is a free agent. He made his [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) debut with the [[Kansas City Royals]] in 2014, and has also played for the [[Atlanta Braves]].
==Career== Adams attended Red Oak High School in [[Red Oak, Oklahoma]]. Playing for the school's basketball team, he scored 3,251 [[point (basketball)|points]], making him the fifth-highest scorer in Oklahoma high school basketball history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballamerica.com/minors/royals-add-upside-to-40-man-roster/ |title=Royals Add Upside To 40-Man Roster |work=Baseball America|first=Alan |last=Eskew |date=December 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 26, 2013|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=David|title=5 things you might not know about Braves rookie Lane Adams|url=https://www.ajc.com/sports/baseball/things-you-might-not-know-about-braves-rookie-lane-adams/kdP2fdl6v6vGVWof5krL4M/|accessdate=February 24, 2018|work=Atlanta Journal Constitution|date=September 16, 2017}}</ref> He committed to attend [[Missouri State University]] on a basketball scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-leader.com/article/20131128/SPORTS0301/311280023/St-Louis-Cardinals-Springfield|title=St. Louis Cardinals - Springfield News-Leader - news-leader.com|work=Springfield News-Leader|accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref>
===Kansas City Royals=== The Royals selected Adams in the 13th round of the [[2009 MLB Draft]], and he signed with the Royals rather than attending college.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eskew|first1=Alan|title=Royals’ Lane Adams Coming Around|url=http://www.baseballamerica.com/majors/royals-lane-adams-coming-around/|accessdate=January 19, 2016|work=Baseball America|subscription=yes|date=May 24, 2013}}</ref>
Adams played for the [[Northwest Arkansas Naturals]] of the [[Class AA]] [[Texas League]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grathoff |first=Pete |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2013/08/11/4404528/a-look-at-mondays-games-in-the.html |title=Lane Adams has three homers, seven RBIs for Naturals |publisher=KansasCity.com |date=August 14, 2013 |accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref> After the 2013 season, the Royals added Adams to their [[40-man roster]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://m.royals.mlb.com/news/article/64080818|title=Royals add four to 40-man roster, drop three |publisher=MLB.com |date=November 20, 2013 |accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref>
On September 1, 2014, the Royals promoted Adams to the major leagues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.royals.mlb.com/news/article/92462198|title=Royals to add three as September callups|publisher=MLB.com|accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref> He made his Major League debut that night, replacing [[Raúl Ibañez]] as a pinch runner in the eighth inning of the Royals' game against the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Hanlon III|first1=Adrian|title=Lane Adams - Red Oak grad working back toward majors|url=http://www.mcalesternews.com/sports/legends-lane-adams---red-oak-grad-working-back/article_4b0dda74-2399-11e5-ad43-c70143ec0015.html|accessdate=January 19, 2016|work=McAlester News-Capital|agency=Associated Press|via=''Washington Times''|deadurl=no|date=July 6, 2015|archiveurl=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jul/20/red-oak-grad-working-back-toward-major-league-base/?page=all|archivedate=July 20, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Grathoff|first1=Pete|title=Lane Adams on his major-league debut: ‘No words to describe the feeling’|url=http://www.kansascity.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/k-zone/article1344550.html|accessdate=January 19, 2016|work=Kansas City Star|date=September 2, 2014}}</ref> He was released in November 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tuesday's Sports Transactions|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-tuesdays-sports-transactions-2015nov03-story.html|accessdate=April 28, 2018|work=San Diego Union Tribune|agency=Associated Press|date=November 3, 2015}}</ref>
===New York Yankees=== Adams spent the 2015 season in the minor leagues. After the season, the [[New York Yankees]] claimed Adams off of [[waivers (baseball)|waivers]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Unruh|first1=Jacob|title=Former Red Oak star Lane Adams claimed on waivers by Yankees|url=http://newsok.com/article/5472905|accessdate=January 18, 2016|work=The Oklahoman|date=January 15, 2016}}</ref>
===Chicago Cubs=== On August 3, 2016, Adams signed a minor league deal with the [[Chicago Cubs]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rocke|first1=Justin|title=Lane Adams Named SL Player of the Week|url=https://www.milb.com/tennessee/news/lane-adams-named-sl-player-of-the-week/c-198314616|accessdate=April 30, 2018|publisher=MILB.com|date=August 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Greene|first1=Adam|title=Tennessee Smokies outfielder Lane Adams received career advice from Cuonzo Martin|url=https://www.knoxnews.com/story/sports/local/2016/08/28/tennessee-smokies-outfielder-lane-adams-received-career-advice-from-cuonzo-martin/91056190/|accessdate=April 30, 2018|work=Knoxville News Sentinel|date=August 28, 2016}}</ref>
===Atlanta Braves=== Adams signed a minor league contract with the [[Atlanta Braves]] organization on December 13, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2016/12/minor-mlb-transactions-121416.html|title=Minor MLB Transactions: 12/14/16|last=Todd|first=Jeff|work=mlbtraderumors.com|date=December 14, 2016|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref> The Braves promoted him to the Major Leagues on April 25, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=David|title=Braves bring Adams up from Triple-A, DFA d’Arnaud|url=https://www.ajc.com/sports/baseball/braves-bring-adams-from-triple-dfa-arnaud/z2NHay24vXTrNeMXaCXlPO/|accessdate=April 27, 2018|work=Atlanta Journal Constitution|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref> Adams recorded his first major league hit in a game against the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] four days later.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Barry|title=Pro baseball: Red Oak's Lane Adams keys Braves' win with 1st MLB hit|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/blogs/sports/probaseball/pro-baseball-red-oak-s-lane-adams-keys-braves-win/article_4c98508b-480e-522b-a137-088ccf9d3606.html|accessdate=April 27, 2018|work=Tulsa World|date=April 29, 2017}}</ref> Adams hit his first major league home run, a three-run shot, against the San Francisco Giants on June 22, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bowman|first1=Mark|title=L. Adams on first MLB HR: 'A great feeling'|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/braves-lane-adams-hits-first-homer-in-majors/c-238224684|accessdate=April 27, 2018|publisher=MLB.com|date=June 23, 2017}}</ref> On September 10, Adams hit a 2-run, walk off home run against the Miami Marlins in the 11th inning.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bowman|first1=Mark|title=L. Adams goes from no invite to walk-off hero|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/braves-lane-adams-hits-walk-off-homer/c-253607634|accessdate=April 27, 2018|publisher=MLB.com|date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> This home run clinched the N.L. East for the Washington Nationals. On April 19, 2018, Adams was designated for assignment by the Braves.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bowman|first1=Mark|title=Freeman in fine form night after HBP scare|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/braves-freddie-freeman-back-after-clean-mri/c-272923376|accessdate=April 28, 2018|publisher=MLB.com|date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> He refused an assignment to the [[Gwinnett Stripers]] and elected free agency on April 27, 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=David|title=Lane Adams opts for free agency; Acuna call-up clogs outfield|url=https://www.ajc.com/sports/baseball/lane-adams-opts-for-free-agency/dih7x19GNP3pMDX7BUVjEL/|accessdate=April 27, 2018|work=Atlanta Journal Constitution|date=April 27, 2018}}</ref>
===Second stint with Chicago Cubs=== On May 5, 2018, Adams signed a minor league deal with the [[Chicago Cubs]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Muskat|first1=Carrie|title=Cubs strike deal with outfielder Adams|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/cubs-strike-deal-with-outfielder-lane-adams/c-275388288|accessdate=May 9, 2018|publisher=MLB.com|date=May 5, 2018}}</ref>
===Second Stint with Braves=== On July 16, 2018, Adams signed a minor league deal with the [[Atlanta Braves]]. He was called up to the major leagues on September 1, 2018. The Braves outrighted him to the minors on October 31, 2018.<ref>https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2018/10/braves-outright-lindgren-ramirez-adams-tucker.html</ref> He elected free agency on November 2.
==Personal life== Adams is a citizen of the [[Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndnsports.com/yankees-claim-outfielder-lane-adams-choctaw-nation-from-the-kansas-city-royals/ |title=Yankees Claim Outfielder Lane Adams (Choctaw Nation) from the K.C. Royals |work=NDNSports.com |date=January 14, 2016 |accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
