{{Infobox military person |name=Ma Haiyan |birth_date=馬海晏 1837 |death_date= 1900 |birth_place=[[Linxia County]], [[Gansu]] |death_place= |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= [[File:Flag of the Qing Dynasty (1889-1912).svg|20px|Flag of the Qing dynasty]] [[Qing dynasty]] |serviceyears=1877–1900 |rank= [[General officer|general]] |commands= |battles=[[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Dungan revolt]]
[[Dungan Revolt (1895)]]
[[Boxer Rebellion]] |laterwork= }}{{Chinese|s=马海晏|t=馬海晏|p=Mǎ Hǎiyàn|xej=ﻣَﺎ ﻫَﻰْ ﻳﯾًﺎ|}} {{Chinese name|[[Ma (surname)|Ma]]}} '''Ma Haiyan''' (1837–1900) was a [[Hui people|Chinese Muslim]] General of the [[Qing Dynasty]]. Originally a rebel, he defected to Qing during the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Dungan revolt]] and helped crush rebel Muslims.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3leAld7M7p0C&pg=PA25 |title=The Temple of Memories: History, Power, and Morality in a Chinese Village|author=Jun Jing|year=1998|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=|page=25|isbn=0-8047-2757-0|pages=|accessdate=28 June 2010}} He was the father of [[Ma Qi]] and [[Ma Lin (warlord)]]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1RuAAAAMAAJ&q=The+three+best+known+of+the+families+in+Gansu+with+the+surname+Ma+were+those+led+by+Ma+Zhan'ao,+Ma+Haiyan+and+Ma+Qianling,+and+it+was+the+son+of+Ma+Haiyan.+Ma+Qi+(+1+869-193+1+),+who+moved+to+Xining+and+set+up+a+military+force+around+...&dq=The+three+best+known+of+the+families+in+Gansu+with+the+surname+Ma+were+those+led+by+Ma+Zhan'ao,+Ma+Haiyan+and+Ma+Qianling,+and+it+was+the+son+of+Ma+Haiyan.+Ma+Qi+(+1+869-193+1+),+who+moved+to+Xining+and+set+up+a+military+force+around+...&hl=en&ei=yHyqTIztEsT38Aaf2sTZBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA|title=Inner Asia, Volume 4, Issues 1-2|author=University of Cambridge. Mongolia & Inner Asia Studies Unit|year=2002|publisher=The White Horse Press for the Mongolia and Inner Asia Studies Unit at the University of Cambridge|location=|page=204|isbn=|pages=|accessdate=28 June 2010}} and of Ma Feng 馬風. [[Dong Fuxiang]], [[Ma Anliang]] and Ma Haiyan were originally called to Beijing during the [[First Sino-Japanese War]] in 1894, but the [[Dungan Revolt (1895)]] broke out and they were subsequently sent to crush the rebels.[http://www.360doc.com/content/10/0526/12/1256060_29592130.shtml 董福祥与西北马家军阀的的故事 - 360Doc个人图书馆] During the [[Hundred Days' Reform]] in 1898 Dong Fuxiang, Ma Anliang, and Ma Haiyan were called to Beijing and helped put an end to the reform movement along with [[Ma Fulu]] and [[Ma Fuxiang]].[http://www.360doc.com/content/10/0526/12/1256060_29592130.shtml 董福祥与西北马家军阀的的故事 - 360Doc个人图书馆] He fought against the foreign Eight Nation Alliance in the [[Boxer Rebellion]] with his nephew [[Ma Biao (general)|Ma Biao]] serving under him, besieged the Catholic Xishiku Cathedral and the legations, and defeated the Alliance at [[Battle of Langfang]], and died of exhaustion while he and the [[Kansu Braves]] were escorting the Imperial family to safety.[http://www.360doc.com/content/11/0917/16/112480_149020067.shtml 民国少数民族将军(组图)2 - 360Doc个人图书馆] His son Ma Qi took over his posts. Ma Biao was the eldest son of Ma Haiqing 馬海清, who was the sixth younger brother of Ma Haiyan, the grandfather of Ma Bufang.[http://www.360doc.com/content/11/0917/16/112480_149020067.shtml 民国少数民族将军(组图)2 - 360Doc个人图书馆] Ma Haiyuan (Ma Hai-yüan) 馬海淵 was the seventh younger brother of Ma Haiyan, father of Ma Guzhong and Ma Bao (Ma Pao) 馬寶, and grandfather of [[Ma Zhongying]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ma Haiyan}} [[Category:19th-century Chinese people]] [[Category:20th-century Chinese people]] [[Category:1900 deaths]] [[Category:People from Linxia]] [[Category:Hui people]] [[Category:Chinese Muslim generals]] [[Category:Qing dynasty generals]] [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:Generals from Gansu]] {{china-mil-bio-stub}} {{China-reli-bio-stub}} {{islam-bio-stub}}

[[File:Magnes the shepherd.jpg|thumb|Illustration of Magnes the shepherd from a 19th-century text]] '''Magnes the shepherd''', sometimes described as '''Magnes the shepherd boy''',{{cite news|newspaper=The Daily Herald|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/44791889/|page=23|title=Compasses Invented by Chinese|date=November 6, 1975}} is a mythological figure, possibly based on a real person, who was cited by [[Pliny the Elder]] (23 CE – 79 CE) as discovering [[Natural remanent magnetization|natural magnetism]]. His name, "Magnes", the Latin word for ''[[magnetite]]'', has been attributed as the origin of the Latin [[Root (linguistics)|root]] that has passed into English, giving its speakers the words ''[[magnet]]'', ''[[magnetism]]'', the mentioned ore, and related formulations. Other authorities have attributed the word origin to other sources. As set out in Pliny's ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Naturalis Historia]]'' ("Natural History"), an early [[encyclopedia]] published c. 77 CE – c. 79 CE,{{cite book|last=Roos|first=Anna Marie|title=The Correspondence of Dr. Martin Lister (1639–1712). Volume One: 1662–1677|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aByoBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA87|year=2015|publisher=[[Brill Publishers]]|location=Leiden, Netherlands|isbn=978-90-04-26332-1|page=87}} and as translated from the Latin in [[Robert Jacobus Forbes]]' ''Studies in Ancient Technology'', Pliny wrote the following (attributing the source of his information, in turn, to [[Nicander|Nicander of Colophon]]):{{cite book|last=Forbes|first=Robert Jacobus|title=Studies in Ancient Technology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbA3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA179|volume=IX|year=1964|publisher=E. J. Brill|location=Leiden, Netherlands|page=179|oclc=180355272}}
Nicander is our authority that it [magnetite ore] was called Magnes from the man who first discovered it on Mount Ida{{Cref2|note 1}} and he is said to have found it when the nails of his shoes and the ferrule of his staff adhered to it, as he was pasturing his herds.
The passage appears at Book XXXVI of ''Naturalis Historia'', covering "The Natural History of Stones", at chapter 25 entitled "The Magnet: Three Remedies".{{cite book|author=Pliny the Elder|translator=John Bostock|translator2=H. T. Riley|title=The Natural History of Pliny|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9zwZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA355|volume=VI|year=1857|publisher=H. G. Bohn|page=355|chapter=The Magnet: Three Remedies|location=London|oclc=615995}} Although Pliny's description is often cited, the story of Magnes the shepherd is postulated by physicist Gillian Turner to be much older, dating from approximately 900 BCE.{{cite book|last=Turner|first=Gillian|title=North Pole, South Pole: The Epic Quest to Solve the Great Mystery of Earth’s Magnetism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UfCC0lAtU_0C&pg=PA6|year=2011|publisher=Awa Press|location=Wellington, NZ|isbn=978-1-61519-132-1|page=6}} Any writings Nicander may have made on the subject have since been [[Lost work|lost]].{{cite book|author=Nicander of Colophon|title=Poems and Poetical Fragments|editors=Translated by A.S.F. Gow, ed. & A.F. Scholfield|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MRvyxRQpklQC&pg=PA216|date=1953|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-14114-7|page=216|orig-year=source text c. 185–136 BCE}} Written in approximately 600 CE, book XVI of ''[[Etymologiae]]'' by [[Isidore of Seville]] tells the same story as Pliny, but places Magnes in India.{{cite book|title=The Etymologies of Isidore of Seville|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3ep502syZv8C&pg=PA319|date=2006|orig-year=source text c. 600 CE|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-45616-6|page=319}} This is repeated in [[Vincent of Beauvais]]' ''Miroir du Monde'' (c. 1250 CE){{cite book|author=Monthly literary register|title=The Monthly magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N2kEAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA571|year=1833|publisher=Charles Tilt|location=London|page=571}} and in Thomas Nicols' 1652 work, ''Lapidary, or, the History of Pretious Stones'', wherein he describes Magnes as a "shepherd of India, who was wont to keep his flocks about those mountains in India, where there was an abundance of [[lodestone]]s".{{cite book|last=Nicols|first=Thomas|title=Lapidary, or, the History of Pretious Stones: With Cautions for the Undeceiving of All Those that Deal with Pretious Stones|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udBEAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA196|year=1652|publisher=Thomas Buck|location=Cambridge|page=196|oclc=12968778}} Following from Pliny's account, the shepherd's name has been often cited as giving rise to the Latin [[Root (linguistics)|root word]] and etymological source of the English word for magnet and the coterie of its related word forms such as ''magnetite'', ''magnet'', ''magnetism'', ''[[magnesium]]'', ''[[manganese]]'' and others.{{cite book|last=Weicker|first=Theodore|title=Merck Report: A Practical Journal of Pharmacy, Materia Medica, and Chemistry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hkI1AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA289|volume=X|year=1901|publisher=Merck & Company|location=New York|page=289|chapter=The Myth of Pliny|oclc=243874912}} Other authorities, including the Roman poet and philosopher [[Lucretius]] ([[circa|c.]] 99 BCE – c. 55 BCE), have attributed the [[etymology]] of ''magnet'', and progeny, to the name of the [[Lydians|Lydian]] city, [[Magnesia ad Sipylum]] ([[Manisa|Manisa, Turkey]] in modern times), where magnetic ore may have first been discovered or recognized.{{cite book|last=Deer|first=William Alexander|title=Rock-forming Minerals: Non-silicates|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ASjwAAAAMAAJ|year=1962|publisher=Longmans|location=London|page=69|oclc=174165277}}{{cite book|last1=Allom|first1=Thomas|last2=Walsh|first2=Robert |title=Constantinople and the scenery of the seven churches of Asia Minor|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dh5fAAAAcAAJ&pg=RA1-PA8-IA6|year=1839|publisher=Fisher, son, & Co|location=London|page=10|oclc=332119}} Other ancient locations have been attributed as the origin, including the Greek province Thracian Magnesia, and the [[Ionia]]n city of [[Magnesia on the Maeander|Magnesia ad Maeandrum]].{{cite book|last=Senning|first=Alexander|title=Elsevier's Dictionary of Chemoetymology: The Whys and Whences of Chemical Nomenclature and Terminology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fl4sdCYrq3cC&pg=PA240|date=2006|publisher=Elsevier|location=Amsterdam|isbn=978-0-08-048881-3|page=240}} The idea that the legend of Magnes the shepherd could be the origin of ''magnet'', et al., and the legend itself has been criticized. Pliny's story is characterized in Gillian Turner's book ''North Pole, South Pole: The Epic Quest to Solve the Great Mystery of Earth’s Magnetism'' (2011) as "no doubt embellished by centuries of retelling." In the 1896 treatise ''Coil and Current; or the Triumphs of Electricity'', the authors write:
'Magnet' is derived from the legend of Magnes, or from the territory of Magnesia. Pliny states that Magnes, the shepherd, discovered it, and the legend told of him is that while carrying a message over Mount Ida he felt his feet clinging to the earth, to the iron ore which lay thickly upon the hill. Hence the name of the Magnet. But Magnesia was a territory whence this native iron was for hundreds of years exported, and the name "Magnet" is, no doubt, due to this place.{{cite book|last1=Frith|first1=Henry|author2=W. Stepney Rawson|title=Coil and Current; or the Triumphs of Electricity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V21YAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA4|year=1896|publisher=Ward, Lock and Co.|location=London|page=4|oclc=8158356}}
==See also== *[[History of geomagnetism]] ==Notes== {{Cnote2 Begin|liststyle=upper-alpha}} {{Cnote2|note 1|There are two "Mount Idas" both featured in Greek Mythology: [[Mount Ida (Turkey)|Mount Ida]] in the ancient [[Troad]] region of western [[Anatolia]] (Asia Minor) (in modern-day [[Turkey]]), and [[Mount Ida (Crete)|Mount Ida]] in [[Crete]]. Pliny does not specify to which mountain Nicander refers. Thus, upon recounting the tale of Magnes the Shepherd, some sources specify the mountain in Asia Minor,{{cite book|last=Zornlin|first=Rosina Maria|title=What is a voltaic battery?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bO8DAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA14|year=1843|location=London|page=14|oclc=319952401}}{{cite book|last=Houston|first=Edwin James|title=The Wonder Book of Magnetism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XxzPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA25|year=1908|publisher=Frederick A. Stokes|location=New York|page=25|oclc=13228559}}{{cite book|last=Schwarcz|first=Joe|title=Dr. Joe's Health Lab: 164 Amazing Insights into the Science of Medicine, Nutrition and Well-being|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tl0kM70L5pgC&pg=PA212|year=2011|publisher=Doubleday Canada|isbn=978-0-385-67157-6|page=212}} and others the mountain in Crete.{{cite book|last=Mangin|first=Arthur|editor=W.H.D. Adams|title=Earth and its treasures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fDwDAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA273|year=1875|publisher=T. Nelson and Sons|location=London|page=273|oclc=5292299}}{{cite book|editor=W.G. Whitman|title=Science Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TsY4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA335|volume=V & VI|year=1922|publisher=W.G. Whitman|location=Salem, Mass.|page=335|oclc=1570576}}{{cite book|title=The Chemistry Leaflet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dxDoAAAAMAAJ|volume=10|year=1936|publisher=Chemistry leaflet.|location=Lancaster, PA|page=502|oclc=1410271}}}} {{Cnote2 End}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=25em}} [[Category:Eponyms]] [[Category:Linguistic root]] [[Category:Magnetism]] [[Category:Fictional shepherds]] [[Category:Mythological characters]]

{{citation style|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Mama Fatima Singhateh | office = [[Minister of Justice (The Gambia)|Minister of Justice]]
[[Attorney General (The Gambia)|Attorney General]] | image = AG mama.jpg | predecessor = [[Aboubacarr Senghore]] | president = [[Yahya Jammeh]] | successor = [[Ba Tambadou]] | term_start = 12 January 2015 | term_end = 17 January 2017 | predecessor1 = [[Amie Joof]] | president1 = [[Yahya Jammeh]] | successor1 = [[Basiru Mahoney]] | term_start1 = 27 August 2013 | term_end1 = 27 August 2014 | party = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | citizenship = | nationality = | otherparty = | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Hull]]
[[University of Wales]] | image_size = | relatives = | education = }} '''Mama Fatima Singhateh''' is a Gambian lawyer, judge, and politician. She served as [[Minister of Justice (The Gambia)|Minister of Justice]] and [[Attorney General of the Gambia]] from 2013 to 2014, and again from 2015 to 2017. From 2009 to 2013, she was a judge in the Gambia.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201501141171.html|title=Gambia: Mama Fatima Singhateh Bounces Back|work=allAfrica.com |date=14 January 2015 |accessdate=19 February 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/gambias-ruler-names-justice-minister-coup-bid-002316289.html|title=Gambia's ruler names new justice minister after coup bid|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://africa.gm/africa/gambia/article/five-gambian-judges-appointed|title=Five Gambian Judges Appointed - Africa.gm - Africa news and information community|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2016}} == Early life and education == Mama Singhateh went through her basic and Secondary School Education in [[Banjul]] The Gambia. She then proceeded to the [[University of Hull]], [[United Kingdom]], from which she graduated with and LLB (Hons) in 1997. She went on to obtain a Masters in International Business Law from the same university in 1998. Between 1998 and 1999 she completed the Bar Vocational Course at the University of Wales and was called to the Bar of England and Wales as Barrister. == Professional career == Before her appointment as Minister Mama Fatima Singhateh held several positions within the Attorney General's Chambers of The Gambia, first as State Counsel in 2002 then as Senior State Counsel and then as Principal Drafts person. Between 2007 and 2009 Mama Singhateh branched into the private sector where she headed the legal Department at one of the International Banks before being appointed Judge of the High Court of The Gambia === Judicial career === In August 2009, upon the recommendation of the Judicial Service Commission, Mama Fatima Singhateh was appointed as Judge of the High Court by His Excellency President [[Yahya Jammeh|Yaya Jammeh]]. Having performed Excellently well in this role she was elevated to the Gambia Court of Appeal in 2012 where she served until her appointment as Minister of Justice. While at the Judiciary Justice Singhateh was the Project Coordinator of the UNDP Justice Sector project{{cite web|url=http://archive.observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/undp-assists-the-judiciary|title=UNDP assists the Judiciary - Daily Observer|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2016}} under which huge strides were made in the administration of justice and improvement in the legal capacity of the judiciary. == Political appointments == In August 2013 Mama Singhateh was appointed to the Cabinet of the Government of The Gambia to occupy the position of Attorney General and Minister of Justice. This appointment was seen as a very strategic one given her previous vast experience within this Ministry. Her stint as Minister saw the launch of major projects within the justice sector, notably the refurbishment of the Ministry's premises{{cite web|url=http://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/article/refurbished-justice-ministry-building-inaugurated|title=Refurbished Justice Ministry building inaugurated - The Point Newspaper, Banjul, The Gambia|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2016}} and for the very first time, the launching of the Single Business Window Registry. [[File:AG rwanda.jpg|thumbnail|Minister SInghateh on Official visit to Rwanda]] She was relieved of her appointment as Minister of Justice in August 2014. In January 2015 she was re-appointed Attorney General and Minister of Justice,{{cite web|url=http://archive.observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/mama-fatima-singhateh-bounces-back|title=Mama Fatima Singhateh bounces back - Daily Observer|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2016}} a position that she currently holds. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Attorneys General of the Gambia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Singhateh, Mama Fatima}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Gambian people]] [[Category:Gambian lawyers]] [[Category:Gambian women in politics]] [[Category:Gambian women lawyers]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Female justice ministers]]

{{Infobox Family | image = | crest = | caption = | name = Mangeshkar family | region = [[Mumbai]], [[India]] | early_forms = | members = [[Deenanath Mangeshkar]]
[[Lata Mangeshkar]]
[[Asha Bhosle]]
[[Usha Mangeshkar]]
[[Meena Khadikar]]
[[Hridaynath Mangeshkar]] | otherfamilies = | traditions = [[Hindu]] | estate = }} The '''Mangeshkar family''' is a prominent Indian family, headed by [[Deenanath Mangeshkar]]. The family is of [[Maharashtra|Maharashtrian]] origin from paternal side and [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]] origin from maternal side.{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Meet-Lata-ben-Mangeshkar/articleshow/5066253.cms|location=[[Ahmedabad]]|title=Meet Lata-ben Mangeshkar!|first=Ashish|last=Vashi|publisher=[[The Times of India]]|date=September 29, 2009}}{{cite news|publisher=[[The Times of India]]|title=Unplugged: Lata Mangeshkar|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/spotlight/Unplugged-Lata-Mangeshkar/articleshow/4625384.cms|date=September 20, 2009}} Many members of the family have been successful singers/music composers in the Hindi film industry.[http://gaurav-kumar.tripod.com/facts.htm Her family and life]{{citation needed|reason=Need better source than blogs|date=March 2018}} ==Overview== ===Deenanath Mangeshkar=== {{see also|Deenanath Mangeshkar}} The father of this famous musical family, Deenanath Mangeshkar was born in 29 December 1900 in the village of [[Mangeshi]], then in Portuguese India to a temple priest and handmaiden of the deity Mangesh.{{cite book|last=Cabral e Sá|first=Mário|title=Wind of fire: the music and musicians of Goa|year=1997|publisher=Promilla & Co.|isbn=978-81-85002-19-4 |page=166}} His father, Ganesh Bhatt Navathe{{cite web|title=Mangeshkar, Dinanath|url=https://marathivishwakosh.maharashtra.gov.in/khandas/khand12/index.php/23-2015-01-14-06-25-27/10237-2012-07-19-05-51-48|website=Marathi VishwaKosh|publisher=Government of Maharashtra|accessdate=30 December 2016}} (Abhisheki), was a [[Karhade Brahmin]] who served as priest at the famous [[Mangueshi Temple]] in [[Goa]] and his mother belonged to [[Gomantak Maratha Samaj]]. The family's last name used to be Hardikar; Deenanath changed it to Mangeshkar in order to identify his family with his native town - Mangeshi. The mother of the family, Shevanti (later renamed Shudhamati), a [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]] woman from [[Thalner]], [[Bombay Presidency]] (now in northwest [[Maharashtra]]), was Deenanath's second wife; his first wife Narmada was Shevanti's older sister, but she died early. The father of Shevanti and Narmada was a Gujarati businessman and landlord Sheth Haridas Ramdas Lad of Thalner. Lata Mangeshkar learnt [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] folk songs such as [[Garba (dance)|garbas]] of [[Pavagadh]] from her maternal grandmother. Deenanath Mangeshkar had 5 children namely [[Lata Mangeshkar]], [[Asha Bhosle]], [[Usha Mangeshkar]], [[Meena Khadikar]] and [[Hridaynath Mangeshkar]].[http://sekho.in/lata-mangeshkar-family-tree-members-upcoming-movies-songs/ Mangeshkar]{{citation needed|reason=Need better source than blog like sites|date=March 2018}} === Lata Mangeshkar === {{see also|Lata Mangeshkar}} Lata Mangeshkar is one of the best-known and most respected playback singers in India. She remained unmarried. === Asha Bhosle === {{see also|Asha Bhosle}} Asha Bhosle is best known as a playback singer in Hindi cinema, although she has a wider repertoire. Asha, at the age of 16, had eloped with 31-year-old Ganpatrao Bhosle. They separated in 1960. They have three children and five grandchildren. The eldest of her three children, Hemant Bhosle (named after [[Hemant Kumar]]), spent most of his early years as a pilot and quit to have a brief career as a music director. Bhosle's daughter [[Varsha Bhosle|Varsha]] committed suicide on 8 October 2012, she was 56 years old and worked as a columnist for ''The Sunday Observer'' and ''[[Rediff]]''.{{cite web | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-10-08/mumbai/34321873_1_singer-asha-bhosle-anand-bhosle-prabhu-kunj | title=Asha's daughter, commits suicide | publisher=Times of India | date=8 October 2012 | accessdate=9 October 2012}} Asha's youngest child, Anand Bhosle, has studied business and film direction. He manages Asha's career. Her grandson, Chaitanya (Chintu) Bhosle (Hemant's son) is a part of the world of music. He is a member of India's first & only [[boy band]], "A Band of Boys". Hemant Bhosle 's best known composed duets were the Kishore Asha duets like Aji Kaho Kya Haal Hai from An padh picturised on Vijendra Ghatke and Sarika and Salamat Raho Tum from same film Anpadh picturised on [[Ashok Kumar]] and [[Sarika]]. Her son Hemant died of cancer in 2015. Hemant's son Chaitanya Bhosle is a singer and has few albums to his name.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2234751/ Chaitanya Bhosle] Asha's first husband Ganpatrao was her personal secretary. Their marriage failed miserably in 1960. Her husband and in-laws mistreated her. After a few years of marriage, Asha was turned out by a suspicious Ganpatrao{{cite web|url=http://www.harmonyindia.org/hportal/VirtualPageView.jsp?page_id=950|title=Only Asha: Asha Bhosle}} and she went to her maternal home with two children and pregnant with her third child. She continued to sing in films to earn money. Asha married [[Rahul Dev Burman]] in 1980.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/I-am-honoured-after-receiving-this-award-Asha-Bhosle/H1-Article1-760281.aspx |title=I am honoured after receiving this award: Asha Bhosle |last=Baksi |first=Dibyojyoti |date=2011-10-22 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=2011-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022185824/http://www.hindustantimes.com/I-am-honoured-after-receiving-this-award-Asha-Bhosle/H1-Article1-760281.aspx |archivedate=2011-10-22 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/125433/more-composer.html |title=More than a composer |author=Ranjan Das Gupta |publisher=''[[Deccan Herald]]'' |accessdate=28 May 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/2010/jun/270610-lata-mangeshkar-rd-burman-71st-birthday.htm |title=I knew him from the time he ran around in shorts |author= Subhash K. Jha |date= 27 June 2010 |newspaper=[[Mid Day]] |location=Mumbai |accessdate=28 May 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-08/news-and-interviews/29863528_1_asha-bhosle-bengali-films-rabindra-sangeet |title=I'm afraid to speak in Bengali: Asha Bhosle |publisher=''[[Times of India]]'' |author=Sreemita Bhattacharya |date=8 Aug 2011 |accessdate=28 May 2012}} This was second marriage for both Rahul and Asha. Rahul, 6 years younger than her, earlier got divorced from Rita Patel in 1971.{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/remembering-r-d-burman-on-his-72nd-birth-anniversary/1/142841.html |title=Remembering R. D. Burman on his 72nd birth anniversary |publisher=''[[India Today]]'' |date=27 June 2011 |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=28 May 2012}} === Usha Mangeshkar === {{see also|Usha Mangeshkar}} Usha Mangeshkar is an Indian singer who has recorded many Hindi, Marathi, Nepali, Bhojpuri and Gujarati songs. She remained unmarried. === Meena Khadikar === {{see also|Meena Khadikar}} Meena Khadikar is an Indian Marathi and Hindi language playback singer and composer. She is also popular for composing various children's songs. She married to Mr. Khadikar who died around 2011. Her son Yogesh Khadikar has recorded a few songs. Yogesh is married to Jitendra Abhisheki's daughter. === Hridaynath Mangeshkar === {{see also|Hridaynath Mangeshkar}} Hridaynath Mangeshkar is a music composer and singer. He is married to Bharati Malvankar Mangeshkar, daughter of Marathi comedian [[Damuanna Malvankar]]. They have two sons [[Aadinath Mangeshkar]] and [[Baijnath Mangeshkar]] and a daughter [[Radha Mangeshkar]]. In 2009, Radha launched her debut album ''Naav Maaza Shaami''. She has been trained by Hridaynath and accompanies him in various stage shows.{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-06-01/news-interviews/28160101_1_lata-mangeshkar-hridaynath-mangeshkar-mangeshkar-family|title=The Gen Y Mangeshkar|work=The Times of India|accessdate=2 September 2015}} == Photo gallery == File:Lata.Mangeshkar.jpg|[[Lata Mangeshkar]] File:Ashaji.jpg|[[Asha Bhosle]] File:Usha Mangeshkar 2007 - still 19426 crop.jpg|[[Usha Mangeshkar]] File:Meena Khadikar.jpg|[[Meena Khadikar]] File:Hridaynath-Mangeshkar-2008.JPG|[[Hridaynath Mangeshkar]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Mangeshkar family}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mangeshkar Family}} [[Category:Indian families]] [[Category:Hindu families]] [[Category:Indian family trees]] [[Category:Family trees]] [[Category:Gujarati people]] [[Category:Konkani people]] [[Category:Marathi people]] [[Category:Mangeshkar family]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Margaret Rock | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 7 July 1903 | birth_place = Hammersmith, London, England | death_date = 26 August 1983 | death_place = Worcester, Worcestershire, England | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = British | education = [[Portsmouth High School (Southsea)|Portsmouth High School]] | alma_mater = Bedford College, University of London | occupation = [[Cryptanalysis]] | employer = | known_for = {{Flatlist| * [[Cryptanalysis|Codebreaking]] at [[Bletchley Park]] }} | salary = | title = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = Frank Ernest Rock, Alice Margaret Simmonds | relatives = John Frank Rock (Brother) Charles Foster | awards = }} '''Margaret Rock''' (7 July 1903 – 26 August 1983) was one of the few women mathematicians who worked in Bletchley Park during [[World War II]]. With her math skills and education, Rock was able to decode the Enigma Machine against the German Army. Her work during the war was classified by the [[Official Secrets Act 1939]], so much of her work was not revealed during her lifetime.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2033674/Bletchley-Park-codebreaker-given-papers-telling-husband-did-working-her.html|title=Codebreaker, 90, handed Bletchley Park papers telling her what her husband did while working with her on Enigma machine|newspaper=Mail Online|access-date=11 October 2016}}</ref>
== Early life == Rock was born and raised in Hammersmith, London to parents of Frank Ernest Rock and Alice Margaret Simmonds.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Dear Codebreaker: The Letters of Margaret Rock|last=Howard|first=Kerry|publisher=BookTower Publishing|year=2016|isbn=|location=Redditch, Worcestershire|pages=280, 355|quote=|via=}}</ref> Rock attended Edmonton elementary and North Middlesex School. Rock's father served in the [[Royal Navy]] as a surgeon between 1894 and 1896 while her mother took care of her and her brother.<ref name=":0" /> Frank Rock would send letters to his children frequently, to stay in communication in 1914, just before World War I.
In 1917, Margaret, her mother and brother settled in Portsmouth, London, after moving frequently for three years.<ref name=":0" /> Rock attended [[Portsmouth High School (Southsea)|Portsmouth High School]], an all female private boarding school. Her father died when HMS Laurentic sank off the coast of Ireland having struck two mines laid by a German [[U-boat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://laurenticmemorial.com/2017/12/29/frank-ernest-rock/|title=Frank Ernest Rock|author=|date=29 December 2017|website=laurenticmemorial.com|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> Rock was encouraged by the letters her late father wrote to her, telling her to keep up with her studies and to be successful in the future. Her brother, John Frank Rock, became a Lieutenant in the Royal Engineers.<ref name=":0" />
== Education == Rock passed the London General School Exam in June 1919.<ref name=":0" /> During high school, she received honours in the classes of French, mathematics, and music.<ref name=":0" /> Rock went to Bedford College, University of London, to earn a Bachelors of Arts Degree in 1921.<ref name=":0" />
After college, Rock was employed as a statistician by the National Association of Manufacturers (The Federation of British Industry).<ref name=":0" /> Rock predicted the economic market and how different businesses and companies would respond to the market. In her free time, Margaret and her brother would travel to different countries such as Italy, France, Switzerland, and Sri Lanka.
== World War II== In the beginning of World War II, Rock and her mother evacuated London to Cranleigh, Surrey.<ref name=":0" /> Margaret quit her old job, wanting a career in a time when the woman's role was primarily to be the wife and stay-at-home mother. She was then recruited for a new job at [[Bletchley Park]] on 15 April 1940.<ref name=":0" /> She worked for Admiral [[Hugh Sinclair|Sir Hugh Sinclair]], who was the Head of Government Code and Cypher School and Secret Intelligence Service. She trained and worked alongside mathematicians and professors to break and decode enemy messages with the Enigma machine. Margaret went to work for [[Dilly Knox|Alfred Dilwyn Knox]], where Margaret worked closely with [[Mavis Lever]] on the same projects. While working for Dilwyn Knox she became the most senior cryptographer. Knox employed women, because he believed they had great skill with cryptography work.<ref name="Margaret Rock">{{Cite news|url=http://spartacus-educational.com/Margaret_Rock.htm|title=Margaret Rock|newspaper=Spartacus Educational|language=en|access-date=3 February 2017}}</ref> Margaret Rock on August 1940, was considered by Dilwyn Knox to be the 4th or 5th best in the whole Enigma staff.<ref name="Margaret Rock"/> She specialized in German and Russian code breaking.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/women-were-key-code-breaking-bletchley-park-180954044/|title=Women Were Key to WWII Code-Breaking at Bletchley Park|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=|language=|access-date=|via=}}</ref> Code breaking was used to verify which individuals in the war were double agents that would skew information and present them as truth.<ref name=":1" />
German Military thought that the Enigma cipher was unbreakable because of the difficult codes it would produce every day.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Colossus: The Secrets of Bletchley Park's Codebreaking Computers|last=Copeland|first=B. Jack|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> The Enigma Machine was not coding fast enough, thus a new device was needed to win the war. By her hard work, Rock was ranked one of the better workers on the [[Enigma machine|Enigma Machine]] project, and was promoted to seniority and a higher salary. On 8 December 1941, the Abwehr Enigma (the German Enigma Machine) message was decoded and read by the team in Bletchley Park by the use of a manuel technique called "rodding" that was identified by Knox.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=99oqAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT132&lpg=PT132&dq=Margaret+Rock+after+the+war#v=onepage&q=Margaret&f=false|title=Codebreakers' Victory: How the Allied Cryptographers Won World War II|last=Haufler|first=Hervie|date=1 April 2014|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=9781497622562|language=en}}</ref> This feat gave an advantage to Britain to plan the [[Normandy landings|D-Day]] attack.<ref name=":0" />
== After the war ==
Rock worked for governmental jobs, such as the Government Communications Headquarters until she retired in 1963.<ref name=":0"/> Because of the Official Secrets Act 1939, Rock never spoke about her work to anyone.<ref name=":0"/> Even late in her life and Bletchley Park and codebreaking was circulating the news, she would not comment about her contribution to the [[Colossus computer|Colossus]]. On 26 August 1983 she died in Ronkswood Hospital, Worcester.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Moe Keale | image = Moe Keale.jpg | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Wilfrid Nalani Keale | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1939|12|03|mf=y}} | birth_place =[[Niihau]], [[Territory of Hawaii]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2002|04|15|1939|12|03}} | death_place =[[Honolulu, Hawaii]] | origin = | instrument = [[Ukulele]] | genre = | occupation = Live performer | years_active = 1958 – 2002 | label = Panini | associated_acts = Moe Keale & Anuenue, Eddie Kamae's Sons Of Hawai'i | website = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Wilfred Nalani "Moe" Keale''' (December 3, 1939 - April 15, 2002) was a musician of [[Music of Hawaii|Hawaiian music]], a [[ukulele]] virtuoso, and an [[United States|American]] [[actor]]. He was the uncle and major musical influence of [[Israel Kamakawiwoʻole]].
==Early life== He was one of the few persons born in the 20th century to have pure [[Native Hawaiians|Hawaiian]] ancestry. His father was a [[kahuna]].<ref name="Retrospective: A Mo`olelo, a Story of Moe's Life">{{Cite web | title=Retrospective: A Mo`olelo, a Story of Moe's Life |author= |first= |last2= |first2= | publisher= | url=http://www.asminor.info/moekeale2020/retrospective.htm| accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref> Moe Keale was born on the island of [[Niihau]], but raised on [[Oahu]]. He was shaped by the ancestral customs and values of his birthplace, learning to play the ukulele at the age of four.<ref name="Great Ukulele Players">{{Cite web | title=Great Ukulele Players |author= |first= |last2= |first2= | publisher=Brudda Bu's Ukulele Heaven | url=http://www.geocities.com/~ukulele/ukeplayers.html| accessdate=20 May 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028045121/http://www.geocities.com/~ukulele/ukeplayers.html|archivedate=2009-10-28}}</ref> Conversations in his Niihau family home were in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], and songs were passed from generation to generation.<ref name="Niihau: The Traditions of an Hawaiian Island">{{cite book | last =Keale Sr| first =Moses |last2=Tava | first2=Rerioterai | title =Niihau: The Traditions of an Hawaiian Island| publisher=Mutual Publishing | year =1990 | isbn =978-0-935180-80-0 }}</ref> He would later fondly recall his summers on Niihau, where stress was not part of the lifestyle. "I figured that heaven must be something like Niihau," he said.<ref name="Masters of Hawaiian Music: Moe Keale">{{Cite web | title=Masters of Hawaiian Music: Moe Keale |author=Lindquist |first=Carl | publisher=CD liner notes | url=http://www.wedey.usanethosting.com/moe.htm| accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref>
==Career== A native of [[Hawaii]], he primarily had roles in movies and TV series that took place in the islands, including many appearances on ''[[Hawaii Five-O (1968 TV series)|Hawaii Five-O]]'', where he had a recurring part as Truck Kealoha in the show's final season. He also appeared as Officer O'Shaughnessy in the Hawaiian-based [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] [[sitcom]], ''[[The Brian Keith Show]]''.
He was a beachboy, musician and singer, part-time electrician, and radio deejay, as well as an actor.<ref name="Entertainers Mourn Moe Keale">{{Cite web | title=Entertainers Mourn Moe Keale |author=Harada |first=Wayne |last2=Gordon |first2=Mike | publisher=Honolulu Advertiser | url=http://www.mjq.net/fiveo/keale.htm| accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref> His first paid musical gig with his group the Four K's was at the Waikiki Tavern circa 1958, followed by the Tropical Club in [[Kailua, Hawaii County, Hawaii|Kailua-Kona]]. In 1964, he worked with the Puka Puka Otea Tahitian Show at Queen's Surf.<ref name="His Songs Made Him a Son of Hawaii Forever">{{cite news |title=His Songs Made Him a Son of Hawaii Forever |last=Bernardo |first=Rosemary |newspaper=Honolulu Star Bulletin|date=24 April 2002 |url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2002/04/24/news/story18.html}}</ref> He was recruited for a New York city gig when he was seen at a beach doing high dives off a simulated waterfall.<ref name="Masters of Hawaiian Music: Moe Keale"/> His most noted role as Truck on ''Hawaii Five-O'' came as a result of his working as an electrician on the set.
Keale and [[Eddie Kamae]] struck up a musical partnership that led to Moe becoming part of the [[Sons of Hawaii]] in 1969,<ref name="Hawaiian Music - A Brief History">{{Cite web | title=Hawaiian Music - A Brief History |author= |first= |last2= |first2= | publisher=Surfing for Life | url=http://www.surfingforlife.com/music.html| accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref> and he remained with the group until 1977. He then went on to make three solo albums ''South Sea Island Magic'', ''Aloha Is A Part of Me, A Part of You'', and ''Imagine''. He was a deejay on [[KCCN]] in the 1980s.<ref name="Entertainers Mourn Moe Keale"/>
From 1984 onward, he and his band played two evenings a week poolside at the [[Sheraton Waikiki]]. It was while performing at the Sheraton that he was struck by the fatal heart attack that ended his life on April 15, 2002.<ref name="Retrospective: A Mo`olelo, a Story of Moe's Life"/>
At the time of his death, he was a hands-on co-owner of the Lomi Shop’s Keiki Wa‘a at the Hyatt Regency Waikiki Resort and Spa at Windward Mall.<ref name="Lomilomi Shop Plays to Canoe Theme">{{cite news |title=Lomilomi Shop Plays to Canoe Theme|last=Nichols |first=Katherine |newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|date=5 January 2001 |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/2001/Jan/05/15islandlife14.html}}</ref> The Lomi Shop promoted the art of healing through [[lomilomi massage]].
Moe had a near-fatal heart attack in April 2001 and received a pacemaker implant. He used his extension on life to raise $260,000 for the [[American Heart Association]], in order to have portable defibrillators strategically positioned throughout the state of Hawaii.<ref name="Retrospective: A Mo`olelo, a Story of Moe's Life"/>
==Recognition== In 2003, the [[Hawai'i Academy of Recording Arts]] instituted the Moe Keale "Aloha Is" Award in its [[Na Hoku Hanohano Awards]].<ref name="Na Hoku Hanohano Award">{{Cite web | title=Na Hoku Hanohano Award | publisher=Hawai‘i Academy of Recording Arts | url=http://www.nahokuhanohano.org/cms/index.php?page=Lifetime-awards | accessdate=20 May 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227155255/http://www.nahokuhanohano.org/cms/index.php?page=Lifetime-awards | archivedate=27 February 2014 | df= }} Hawai‘i Academy of Recording Arts</ref>
